{"uri": "2024-06-394145139", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:33:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:33:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:32:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.ksbw.com/article/kansas-kansas-city-chiefs-new-stadiums/61165205", "title": "Kansas is making a big run at Kansas City's pro teams with a plan to help pay for new stadiums", "body": "Kansas is making a serious run at becoming the new home for the reigning Super Bowl champions with legislators approving a plan Tuesday for luring both the Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Kansas City Royals away from Missouri. Bipartisan legislative supermajorities OKed the measure to authorize state bonds to help finance new stadiums and practice facilities for both teams on the Kansas side of the metropolitan area of 2.3 million residents, which is split by the border with Missouri. Three Super Bowl victories in five years -- and player Travis Kelce's romance with pop icon Taylor Swift -- have made the Chiefs perhaps the area's most celebrated civic asset.The plan from the Republican-controlled Legislature goes next to Democratic Gov. Laura Kelly. While she stopped short of promising to sign it, she said in a statement that \"Kansas now has the opportunity to become a professional sports powerhouse.\"Both the Chiefs and the Royals said they look forward to considering Kansas options. The lease on the Missouri complex with their side-by-side stadiums runs through January 2031, but both have said they already should have been planning for the future. \"We're excited about what happened here today,\" Korb Maxwell, an attorney for the Chiefs who lives on the Kansas side, said at the Statehouse after the bill cleared the Legislature. \"This is incredibly real.\" The approval capped a two-month push to capitalize on the refusal in April by voters on the Missouri side to continue a local sales tax used to finance the upkeep of the teams' stadiums. Backers of the plan brushed aside decades of research by economists concluding that government subsidies for professional sports stadiums are not worth the cost. They also overcame criticism that lawmakers were moving too quickly.A spokeswoman for Missouri Gov. Mike Parson did not immediately respond to an email message seeking comment. But in Kansas City, Missouri, Mayor Quinton Lucas promised to \"lay out a good offer\" to keep both teams in town.\"Today was largely, in my opinion, about leverage,\" Lucas said. \"And the teams are in an exceptional leverage position.\" Some Kansas officials reached the same conclusion.\"I think the Chiefs and the Royals are using us,\" said state Rep. Susan Ruiz, a Kansas City-area Democrat. The votes on the Kansas stadium-financing plan were 84-38 in the state House and 27-8 in the Senate. Lawmakers from across the state -- even western Kansas, far from any new stadium -- supported the measure. It would allow state bonds to cover up to 70% of each new stadium, paying them off over 30 years with revenues from sports betting, state lottery ticket sales and new sales and alcohol taxes collected from shopping and entertainment districts around the new stadiums.House Commerce Committee Chair Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican, said the Chiefs still are likely to spend $500 million to $700 million in private funds on a new stadium.\"There are no blank checks,\" Tarwater told GOP colleagues during a briefing. Legislators debated the plan during a one-day special session called by Kelly to have them consider reducing taxes after she vetoed three tax-cutting plans before legislators adjourned their regular annual session May 1. Republican leaders had promised that the stadium proposal wouldn't come up until the Legislature first approved a plan to cut income and property taxes by a total of $1.23 billion over the next three years. Many lawmakers argued that voters would be angry if the state helped finance new stadiums without cutting taxes. With the tax bill passed, the stadium plan gained support even from lawmakers who saw it as a handout for wealthy team owners. Some said failing to act risked pushing the teams to leave the Kansas City area, and a few said they had wanted the Chiefs in Kansas since childhood.\"It is amazing to me the speed with which we can solve problems when they're oriented around wealth, when they're oriented around business,\" said state Rep. Jason Probst, a Democrat from central Kansas.Yet Probst voted for the bill. \"This is the system that we're stuck in, so if we choose to opt out of that system, we will lose every time,\" he said. Economists who study pro sports teams have concluded in dozens of studies that a new stadium and shopping-and-entertainment area merely takes existing economic activity away from elsewhere in a community, resulting in little or no net gain. \"It could still help Kansas and maybe hurt Missouri by the same amount,\" said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith college in central Massachusetts who has written multiple books about sports. \"It's a zero-sum game.\" A skeptical state Sen. Molly Baumgardner, a Kansas City-area Republican, used a Christmas Eve metaphor to characterize supporters' excitement before she voted no. \"There are visions of sugar plums,\" Baumgardner said.\n\nKansas is making a serious run at becoming the new home for the reigning Super Bowl champions with legislators approving a plan Tuesday for luring both the Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Kansas City Royals away from Missouri.\n\nBipartisan legislative supermajorities OKed the measure to authorize state bonds to help finance new stadiums and practice facilities for both teams on the Kansas side of the metropolitan area of 2.3 million residents, which is split by the border with Missouri. Three Super Bowl victories in five years -- and player Travis Kelce's romance with pop icon Taylor Swift -- have made the Chiefs perhaps the area's most celebrated civic asset.\n\nThe plan from the Republican-controlled Legislature goes next to Democratic Gov. Laura Kelly. While she stopped short of promising to sign it, she said in a statement that \"Kansas now has the opportunity to become a professional sports powerhouse.\"\n\nBoth the Chiefs and the Royals said they look forward to considering Kansas options. The lease on the Missouri complex with their side-by-side stadiums runs through January 2031, but both have said they already should have been planning for the future.\n\n\"We're excited about what happened here today,\" Korb Maxwell, an attorney for the Chiefs who lives on the Kansas side, said at the Statehouse after the bill cleared the Legislature. \"This is incredibly real.\"\n\nThe approval capped a two-month push to capitalize on the refusal in April by voters on the Missouri side to continue a local sales tax used to finance the upkeep of the teams' stadiums.\n\nBackers of the plan brushed aside decades of research by economists concluding that government subsidies for professional sports stadiums are not worth the cost. They also overcame criticism that lawmakers were moving too quickly.\n\nA spokeswoman for Missouri Gov. Mike Parson did not immediately respond to an email message seeking comment. But in Kansas City, Missouri, Mayor Quinton Lucas promised to \"lay out a good offer\" to keep both teams in town.\n\n\"Today was largely, in my opinion, about leverage,\" Lucas said. \"And the teams are in an exceptional leverage position.\"\n\nSome Kansas officials reached the same conclusion.\n\n\"I think the Chiefs and the Royals are using us,\" said state Rep. Susan Ruiz, a Kansas City-area Democrat.\n\nThe votes on the Kansas stadium-financing plan were 84-38 in the state House and 27-8 in the Senate. Lawmakers from across the state -- even western Kansas, far from any new stadium -- supported the measure.\n\nIt would allow state bonds to cover up to 70% of each new stadium, paying them off over 30 years with revenues from sports betting, state lottery ticket sales and new sales and alcohol taxes collected from shopping and entertainment districts around the new stadiums.\n\nHouse Commerce Committee Chair Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican, said the Chiefs still are likely to spend $500 million to $700 million in private funds on a new stadium.\n\n\"There are no blank checks,\" Tarwater told GOP colleagues during a briefing.\n\nLegislators debated the plan during a one-day special session called by Kelly to have them consider reducing taxes after she vetoed three tax-cutting plans before legislators adjourned their regular annual session May 1.\n\nRepublican leaders had promised that the stadium proposal wouldn't come up until the Legislature first approved a plan to cut income and property taxes by a total of $1.23 billion over the next three years. Many lawmakers argued that voters would be angry if the state helped finance new stadiums without cutting taxes.\n\nWith the tax bill passed, the stadium plan gained support even from lawmakers who saw it as a handout for wealthy team owners. Some said failing to act risked pushing the teams to leave the Kansas City area, and a few said they had wanted the Chiefs in Kansas since childhood.\n\n\"It is amazing to me the speed with which we can solve problems when they're oriented around wealth, when they're oriented around business,\" said state Rep. Jason Probst, a Democrat from central Kansas.\n\nYet Probst voted for the bill.\n\n\"This is the system that we're stuck in, so if we choose to opt out of that system, we will lose every time,\" he said.\n\nEconomists who study pro sports teams have concluded in dozens of studies that a new stadium and shopping-and-entertainment area merely takes existing economic activity away from elsewhere in a community, resulting in little or no net gain.\n\n\"It could still help Kansas and maybe hurt Missouri by the same amount,\" said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith college in central Massachusetts who has written multiple books about sports. \"It's a zero-sum game.\"\n\nA skeptical state Sen. Molly Baumgardner, a Kansas City-area Republican, used a Christmas Eve metaphor to characterize supporters' excitement before she voted no.\n\n\"There are visions of sugar plums,\" Baumgardner said.", {"uri": "2024-06-395053945", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:26:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:26:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:08:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/missouri-mayor-says-fight-over-180832300.html", "title": "A Missouri mayor says a fight over jobs is back on. Things to know about Kansas wooing the Chiefs", "body": "TOPEKA, Kan. (AP) -- A plan in Kansas for luring the Kansas City's two major league sports franchises from Missouri has prompted their hometown's mayor to declare that the move ends a 5-year-old agreement by the states not to poach each other's jobs.\n\nThe Kansas Legislature has approved a measure to allow the state to issue bonds to help the Super Bowl Champion Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Royals pay for new stadiums in Kansas. It goes next to Gov. Laura Kelly.\n\nHere are a few things to know about the two states' contest for the teams.\n\nKansas is poised to make offers\n\nWhile Kelly has not formally pledged to sign the stadium-financing bill, she issued a positive statement when it passed Tuesday, saying it could make Kansas \"a professional sports powerhouse.\" If she signs it, as many lawmakers expect, it would take effect July 1.\n\nThe state's secretary of commerce, Lt. Gov. David Toland, would negotiate with one or both teams on a plan for a new stadium. Kelly and eight top legislative leaders would have to approve each deal with a vote in a public meeting.\n\nA deal would draw the boundaries of a district around a stadium and possibly another around a separate practice facility, and new state sales and alcohol tax revenues generated by shops, restaurants, bars and hotels within that district would pay off the bonds over 30 years.\n\nThe city and county could pledge tax revenues as well but are not required to do so, and the state also could use revenues from sports betting and state lottery ticket sales to back bonds as well.\n\nThe bonds could cover up to 70% of the costs of the new stadiums, though supporters of the plan don't expect that, anticipating that two stadiums together could cost $4 billion.\n\nThere is talk of a renewed economic 'border war'\n\nThe Kansas-Missouri border splits the 2.3 million-resident Kansas City area, and there's both Kansas City, Missouri, and Kansas City, Kansas. Much of the border is the median of State Line Road, and about 60% of the area's residents live on the Missouri side.\n\nA feud between the two states has existed for generations and most recently saw each state burning through tens of millions of dollars in subsides to pull existing businesses across the border. Officials on both sides came to see the contest as expensive and wasteful, and in 2019, Kelly, a Democrat, and Missouri Gov. Mike Parson, a Republican, signed a truce.\n\nKansas City, Missouri Mayor Quinton Lucas told reporters that Kansas' bid for the Chiefs and Royals restarted that economic \"border war.\"\n\n\"I do believe long-term that we're one place and it's better when we work together,\" he said during a news conference.\n\nBut Kelly doesn't agree that the states' truce has been violated, telling reporters this week that before the agreement, \"We never discussed the teams.\"\n\nKansas lawmakers tapped fears about the future\n\nKansas lawmakers acted after voters on the Missouri side refused in April to extend a local sales tax for keeping up the complex with the teams' side-by-side stadiums. Many Kansas lawmakers worried that if they didn't act, the teams might move out of the area altogether -- mentioning Salt Lake City, San Antonio and Nashville.\n\nSeveral economists who've studied professional sports were dubious that moving would make financial sense for either team -- especially the Chiefs, who have a rabid fan base that could be hard to build quickly elsewhere. In addition, after pro football's Rams moved nearly a decade ago from St. Louis to Los Angeles, the team's owner and the National Football League paid $790 million to settle a lawsuit filed by St. Louis interests.\n\nBut Kansas lawmakers noted that the Royals' major-league predecessor, the Athletics, moved to Oakland, California, in 1968 and now plan to relocate to Las Vegas. Kansas City lost major-league professional teams to other cities in the 1970s and 1980s, and the Chiefs came to Kansas City in 1963 after starting as the Dallas Texans four years earlier.\n\n\"The state of Missouri is known for losing professional teams,\" Kansas state Rep. Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican, who helped lead the push for the stadium bill.\n\nKansas officials expect Missouri to respond\n\nMissouri officials have pledged to do what it takes to keep the Chiefs and Royals in their state but have not outlined specific proposals. Lucas saw the April vote as a sign that area residents wanted officials to discuss options other than extending the sales tax.\n\nLike their counterparts in Kansas, Missouri lawmakers have finished their annual regular session, but they are set to meet again Sept. 11 to consider vetoes by Parson.\n\nSupporters of Kansas' bid for the teams said it could spur an aggressive response from Missouri -- and added that if the teams get offers they like and opt to stay there, at least they're still in the Kansas City area.\n\nLucas said the teams now have \"exceptional leverage.\"\n\nKansas and Missouri describe the timeline differently\n\nThe lease on the complex with the Chiefs' and Royals' existing stadiums runs through January 2031, but the teams have said they must plan renovations or new stadiums years in advance for them to be ready on time. Both suggested that even seven years out, time for a decision is short.\n\nBackers of the Kansas bid said such comments justified acting Tuesday, during a one-day special session that Kelly called to consider tax cuts after lawmakers adjourned their regular annual session May 1. Some critics argued that legislators should have waited until their regular 2025 session starts in January so a plan could be properly vetted.\n\nBut Parson and Lucas have said the contest for the teams is only in its \"first quarter,\" using a football metaphor.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Summer Ballentine, in Columbia, Missouri, and Jim Salter, in O'Fallon, Missouri, also contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "john_hanna@yahoo.com", "name": "John Hanna", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], {"uri": "2024-06-395048482", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:20:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:20:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:08:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/sports/articles/2024-06-19/a-missouri-mayor-says-a-fight-over-jobs-is-back-on-things-to-know-about-kansas-wooing-the-chiefs", "title": "A Missouri Mayor Says a Fight Over Jobs Is Back On. Things to Know About Kansas Wooing the Chiefs", "body": "TOPEKA, Kan. (AP) -- A plan in Kansas for luring the Kansas City's two major league sports franchises from Missouri has prompted their hometown's mayor to declare that the move ends a 5-year-old agreement by the states not to poach each other's jobs.\n\nThe Kansas Legislature has approved a measure to allow the state to issue bonds to help the Super Bowl Champion Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Royals pay for new stadiums in Kansas. It goes next to Gov. Laura Kelly.\n\nHere are a few things to know about the two states' contest for the teams.\n\nKansas is poised to make offers\n\nWhile Kelly has not formally pledged to sign the stadium-financing bill, she issued a positive statement when it passed Tuesday, saying it could make Kansas \"a professional sports powerhouse.\" If she signs it, as many lawmakers expect, it would take effect July 1.\n\nThe state's secretary of commerce, Lt. Gov. David Toland, would negotiate with one or both teams on a plan for a new stadium. Kelly and eight top legislative leaders would have to approve each deal with a vote in a public meeting.\n\nA deal would draw the boundaries of a district around a stadium and possibly another around a separate practice facility, and new state sales and alcohol tax revenues generated by shops, restaurants, bars and hotels within that district would pay off the bonds over 30 years.\n\nThe city and county could pledge tax revenues as well but are not required to do so, and the state also could use revenues from sports betting and state lottery ticket sales to back bonds as well.\n\nThe bonds could cover up to 70% of the costs of the new stadiums, though supporters of the plan don't expect that, anticipating that two stadiums together could cost $4 billion.\n\nThere is talk of a renewed economic 'border war'\n\nThe Kansas-Missouri border splits the 2.3 million-resident Kansas City area, and there's both Kansas City, Missouri, and Kansas City, Kansas. Much of the border is the median of State Line Road, and about 60% of the area's residents live on the Missouri side.\n\nA feud between the two states has existed for generations and most recently saw each state burning through tens of millions of dollars in subsides to pull existing businesses across the border. Officials on both sides came to see the contest as expensive and wasteful, and in 2019, Kelly, a Democrat, and Missouri Gov. Mike Parson, a Republican, signed a truce.\n\nKansas City, Missouri Mayor Quinton Lucas told reporters that Kansas' bid for the Chiefs and Royals restarted that economic \"border war.\"\n\n\"I do believe long-term that we're one place and it's better when we work together,\" he said during a news conference.\n\nBut Kelly doesn't agree that the states' truce has been violated, telling reporters this week that before the agreement, \"We never discussed the teams.\"\n\nKansas lawmakers tapped fears about the future\n\nKansas lawmakers acted after voters on the Missouri side refused in April to extend a local sales tax for keeping up the complex with the teams' side-by-side stadiums. Many Kansas lawmakers worried that if they didn't act, the teams might move out of the area altogether -- mentioning Salt Lake City, San Antonio and Nashville.\n\nSeveral economists who've studied professional sports were dubious that moving would make financial sense for either team -- especially the Chiefs, who have a rabid fan base that could be hard to build quickly elsewhere. In addition, after pro football's Rams moved nearly a decade ago from St. Louis to Los Angeles, the team's owner and the National Football League paid $790 million to settle a lawsuit filed by St. Louis interests.\n\nBut Kansas lawmakers noted that the Royals' major-league predecessor, the Athletics, moved to Oakland, California, in 1968 and now plan to relocate to Las Vegas. Kansas City lost major-league professional teams to other cities in the 1970s and 1980s, and the Chiefs came to Kansas City in 1963 after starting as the Dallas Texans four years earlier.\n\n\"The state of Missouri is known for losing professional teams,\" Kansas state Rep. Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican, who helped lead the push for the stadium bill.\n\nKansas officials expect Missouri to respond\n\nMissouri officials have pledged to do what it takes to keep the Chiefs and Royals in their state but have not outlined specific proposals. Lucas saw the April vote as a sign that area residents wanted officials to discuss options other than extending the sales tax.\n\nLike their counterparts in Kansas, Missouri lawmakers have finished their annual regular session, but they are set to meet again Sept. 11 to consider vetoes by Parson.\n\nSupporters of Kansas' bid for the teams said it could spur an aggressive response from Missouri -- and added that if the teams get offers they like and opt to stay there, at least they're still in the Kansas City area.\n\nLucas said the teams now have \"exceptional leverage.\"\n\nKansas and Missouri describe the timeline differently\n\nThe lease on the complex with the Chiefs' and Royals' existing stadiums runs through January 2031, but the teams have said they must plan renovations or new stadiums years in advance for them to be ready on time. Both suggested that even seven years out, time for a decision is short.\n\nBackers of the Kansas bid said such comments justified acting Tuesday, during a one-day special session that Kelly called to consider tax cuts after lawmakers adjourned their regular annual session May 1. Some critics argued that legislators should have waited until their regular 2025 session starts in January so a plan could be properly vetted.\n\nBut Parson and Lucas have said the contest for the teams is only in its \"first quarter,\" using a football metaphor.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Summer Ballentine, in Columbia, Missouri, and Jim Salter, in O'Fallon, Missouri, also contributed to this story.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "2024-06-394106360", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "02:22:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T02:22:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T02:11:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/kansas-is-making-a-big-run-at-kansas-citys-pro-teams-with-a-plan-to/article_dc98ca4b-bf77-588e-8343-0d0c9b127e21.html", "title": "Kansas is making a big run at Kansas City's pro teams with a plan to help pay for new stadiums", "body": "Kansas is making a serious run at becoming the new home for the Super Bowl champion Kansas City Chiefs\n\nTOPEKA, Kan. (AP) -- Kansas is making a serious run at becoming the new home for the reigning Super Bowl champions with legislators approving a plan Tuesday for luring both the Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Kansas City Royals away from Missouri.\n\nBipartisan legislative supermajorities OKed the measure to authorize state bonds to help finance new stadiums and practice facilities for both teams on the Kansas side of the metropolitan area of 2.3 million residents, which is split by the border with Missouri. Three Super Bowl victories in five years -- and player Travis Kelce's romance with pop icon Taylor Swift -- have made the Chiefs perhaps the area's most celebrated civic asset.\n\nThe plan from the Republican-controlled Legislature goes next to Democratic Gov. Laura Kelly. While she stopped short of promising to sign it, she said in a statement that \"Kansas now has the opportunity to become a professional sports powerhouse.\"\n\nBoth the Chiefs and the Royals said they look forward to considering Kansas options. The lease on the Missouri complex with their side-by-side stadiums runs through January 2031, but both have said they already should have been planning for the future.\n\n\"We're excited about what happened here today,\" Korb Maxwell, an attorney for the Chiefs who lives on the Kansas side, said at the Statehouse after the bill cleared the Legislature. \"This is incredibly real.\"\n\nThe approval capped a two-month push to capitalize on the refusal in April by voters on the Missouri side to continue a local sales tax used to finance the upkeep of the teams' stadiums.\n\nBackers of the plan brushed aside decades of research by economists concluding that government subsidies for professional sports stadiums are not worth the cost. They also overcame criticism that lawmakers were moving too quickly.\n\nA spokeswoman for Missouri Gov. Mike Parson did not immediately respond to an email message seeking comment. But in Kansas City, Missouri, Mayor Quinton Lucas promised to \"lay out a good offer\" to keep both teams in town.\n\n\"Today was largely, in my opinion, about leverage,\" Lucas said. \"And the teams are in an exceptional leverage position.\"\n\nSome Kansas officials reached the same conclusion.\n\n\"I think the Chiefs and the Royals are using us,\" said state Rep. Susan Ruiz, a Kansas City-area Democrat.\n\nThe votes on the Kansas stadium-financing plan were 84-38 in the state House and 27-8 in the Senate. Lawmakers from across the state -- even western Kansas, far from any new stadium -- supported the measure.\n\nIt would allow state bonds to cover up to 70% of each new stadium, paying them off over 30 years with revenues from sports betting, state lottery ticket sales and new sales and alcohol taxes collected from shopping and entertainment districts around the new stadiums.\n\nHouse Commerce Committee Chair Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican, said the Chiefs still are likely to spend $500 million to $700 million in private funds on a new stadium.\n\n\"There are no blank checks,\" Tarwater told GOP colleagues during a briefing.\n\nLegislators debated the plan during a one-day special session called by Kelly to have them consider reducing taxes after she vetoed three tax-cutting plans before legislators adjourned their regular annual session May 1.\n\nRepublican leaders had promised that the stadium proposal wouldn't come up until the Legislature first approved a plan to cut income and property taxes by a total of $1.23 billion over the next three years. Many lawmakers argued that voters would be angry if the state helped finance new stadiums without cutting taxes.\n\nWith the tax bill passed, the stadium plan gained support even from lawmakers who saw it as a handout for wealthy team owners. Some said failing to act risked pushing the teams to leave the Kansas City area, and a few said they had wanted the Chiefs in Kansas since childhood.\n\n\"It is amazing to me the speed with which we can solve problems when they're oriented around wealth, when they're oriented around business,\" said state Rep. Jason Probst, a Democrat from central Kansas.\n\nYet Probst voted for the bill.\n\n\"This is the system that we're stuck in, so if we choose to opt out of that system, we will lose every time,\" he said.\n\nEconomists who study pro sports teams have concluded in dozens of studies that a new stadium and shopping-and-entertainment area merely takes existing economic activity away from elsewhere in a community, resulting in little or no net gain.\n\n\"It could still help Kansas and maybe hurt Missouri by the same amount,\" said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith college in central Massachusetts who has written multiple books about sports. \"It's a zero-sum game.\"\n\nA skeptical state Sen. Molly Baumgardner, a Kansas City-area Republican, used a Christmas Eve metaphor to characterize supporters' excitement before she voted no.\n\n\"There are visions of sugar plums,\" Baumgardner said.\n\nMore from this section\n\nLatinx Festival on L. Ron Hubbard Way Celebrates Diversity, Community, Friendship and Empowerment\n\nOver 75 million people in the US are under heat alerts. {"uri": "8185915425", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "20:29:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T20:29:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T20:27:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.givemesport.com/kansas-lawmakers-approve-plan-attract-chiefs-away-missouri/", "title": "Kansas Lawmakers Approve Plan to Attract Chiefs Away From Missouri", "body": "Highlights Kansas lawmakers have approved funding for a new Chiefs stadium, anticipating a significant economic impact for the state. Kansas plans to cover 70% of the new stadium's costs, aiming to attract major professional sports teams. The Chiefs and Royals are set to relocate to Kansas after Missouri residents reject funding proposals.\n\nLawmakers in the state of Kansas ruled in favor of a plan to fund a new stadium for the Kansas City Chiefs, thereby luring them away from Missouri.\n\nThe decision to sanction state bonds was authorized as bipartisan legislative supermajorities gave their consent. The bill, which was passed on Tuesday, was sent to Governor Laura Kelly.\n\nAccording to AP News, Kelly hasn't committed to signing it yet, but she didn't fail to appreciate the work put into the stadium-financing bill:\n\nKansas now has the opportunity to become a professional sports powerhouse. We're excited about what happened here today; this is incredibly real. In my opinion, today was largely about leverage. The teams are in an exceptional leverage position, but it's important to remember that there are no blank checks.\n\nThe bill would mean that Kansas would cover as much as 70% of a new stadium to house the Chiefs and Major League Baseball side, the Kansas City Royals. This percentage is far greater than what Las Vegas offered the Raiders under similar circumstances.\n\nThe Kansas lawmakers anticipate revenue from sports betting, state lottery ticket sales, and new sales and alcohol taxes collected from shopping and entertainment districts around the new stadiums.\n\nRelated NFL Trade Rumors: Kansas City Chiefs Trade Targets and Candidates\n\nThe reigning Super Bowl champions could have some additional offseason moves in store.\n\nChiefs Always Wanted in Kansas The Chiefs coming to Kansas is the dream of many\n\nArrowhead and Kauffman stadiums, belonging to the Chiefs and Royals respectively, have been the major stadiums in Kansas City, Missouri for quite some time, with Arrowhead debuting in 1972 and Kauffman opening up for business a year later, in 1973.\n\nHowever, the decision reached by the Kansas legislators is about to bring both teams to the Kansas side of the metropolitan area. Unsurprisingly, the Chiefs and the Royals seem like they're embracing the decision. Korb Maxwell, an attorney for the Chiefs, expressed his excitement when the bill passed:\n\nWe're excited about what happened here today. This is incredibly real.\n\nDespite the large contributions proposed to cover the new stadium's finances, the Chiefs are still likely to commit up to $700 million in private funds to the project. This was made clear by House Commerce Committee chair Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican.\n\nThe push to pass the bill was fueled by Missouri side residents' refusal to continue funding the stadium of professional teams.\n\nThe people of Jackson County, Missouri, decisively rejected a sales tax proposal to finance a new downtown ballpark and extensive upgrades to Arrowhead Stadium. They deemed government subsidies for professional sports an unworthy endeavor.\n\nFollowing the clearing of the bill, the mayor of Kansas, Missouri, Quinton Lucas, didn't have much to say, only promising to \"lay out a good offer\" to keep the pro teams in Missouri. Many lawmakers embraced the decision to finance a new stadium for the Chiefs in Kansas. This was reflected in the vote margin, as the votes were 84-38 in the State House and 27-8 in the Senate.\n\nSurprisingly, even lawmakers from Western Kansas were in support of the Kansas stadium-financing plan. For many, it is a smart business idea that will favor wealthy team owners. State Rep. Jason Probst, a Democrat from Central Kansas, having voted for the bill, said:\n\nIt is amazing to me the speed with which we can solve problems when they're oriented around wealth, when they're oriented around business. This is the system that we're stuck in, so if we choose to opt out of that system, we will lose every time.\n\nThe Chiefs are one of the most promising franchises in the sport with a growing fanbase -- extra thanks to Travis Kelce's relationship with Taylor Swift. However, economists specializing in pro sports don't expect the passed bill to create much economic net change.\n\nAndrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College, called it a \"zero-sum game\". Sen. Molly Baumgardner, a Kansas City-area Republican, wasn't sure what to make of the situation.\n\nShe didn't seem to buy the idea. For her, they were \"visions of sugar plums\".\n\nSource: AP News\n\nAll statistics courtesy of Pro Football Reference unless stated otherwise.\n\nRelated Three Best Offseason Moves For The Kansas {"uri": "8184530243", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "02:25:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T02:25:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T02:24:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/article/0bc5f4e1ea6a9387a0a34df23a1488e5/kansas-making-big-run-kansas-citys-pro-teams-plan-help-pay", "title": "Kansas is making a big run at Kansas City's pro teams with a plan to help pay for new stadiums", "body": "TOPEKA, Kan. (AP) -- Kansas is making a serious run at becoming the new home for the reigning Super Bowl champions with legislators approving a plan Tuesday for luring both the Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Kansas City Royals away from Missouri.\n\nBipartisan legislative supermajorities OKed the measure to authorize state bonds to help finance new stadiums and practice facilities for both teams on the Kansas side of the metropolitan area of 2.3 million residents, which is split by the border with Missouri. Three Super Bowl victories in five years -- and player Travis Kelce's romance with pop icon Taylor Swift -- have made the Chiefs perhaps the area's most celebrated civic asset.\n\nThe plan from the Republican-controlled Legislature goes next to Democratic Gov. Laura Kelly. While she stopped short of promising to sign it, she said in a statement that \"Kansas now has the opportunity to become a professional sports powerhouse.\"\n\nBoth the Chiefs and the Royals said they look forward to considering Kansas options. The lease on the Missouri complex with their side-by-side stadiums runs through January 2031, but both have said they already should have been planning for the future.\n\n\"We're excited about what happened here today,\" Korb Maxwell, an attorney for the Chiefs who lives on the Kansas side, said at the Statehouse after the bill cleared the Legislature. \"This is incredibly real.\"\n\nThe approval capped a two-month push to capitalize on the refusal in April by voters on the Missouri side to continue a local sales tax used to finance the upkeep of the teams' stadiums.\n\nBackers of the plan brushed aside decades of research by economists concluding that government subsidies for professional sports stadiums are not worth the cost. They also overcame criticism that lawmakers were moving too quickly.\n\nA spokeswoman for Missouri Gov. Mike Parson did not immediately respond to an email message seeking comment. But in Kansas City, Missouri, Mayor Quinton Lucas promised to \"lay out a good offer\" to keep both teams in town.\n\n\"Today was largely, in my opinion, about leverage,\" Lucas said. \"And the teams are in an exceptional leverage position.\"\n\nSome Kansas officials reached the same conclusion.\n\n\"I think the Chiefs and the Royals are using us,\" said state Rep. Susan Ruiz, a Kansas City-area Democrat.\n\nThe votes on the Kansas stadium-financing plan were 84-38 in the state House and 27-8 in the Senate. Lawmakers from across the state -- even western Kansas, far from any new stadium -- supported the measure.\n\nIt would allow state bonds to cover up to 70% of each new stadium, paying them off over 30 years with revenues from sports betting, state lottery ticket sales and new sales and alcohol taxes collected from shopping and entertainment districts around the new stadiums.\n\nHouse Commerce Committee Chair Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican, said the Chiefs still are likely to spend $500 million to $700 million in private funds on a new stadium.\n\n\"There are no blank checks,\" Tarwater told GOP colleagues during a briefing.\n\nLegislators debated the plan during a one-day special session called by Kelly to have them consider reducing taxes after she vetoed three tax-cutting plans before legislators adjourned their regular annual session May 1.\n\nRepublican leaders had promised that the stadium proposal wouldn't come up until the Legislature first approved a plan to cut income and property taxes by a total of $1.23 billion over the next three years. Many lawmakers argued that voters would be angry if the state helped finance new stadiums without cutting taxes.\n\nWith the tax bill passed, the stadium plan gained support even from lawmakers who saw it as a handout for wealthy team owners. Some said failing to act risked pushing the teams to leave the Kansas City area, and a few said they had wanted the Chiefs in Kansas since childhood.\n\n\"It is amazing to me the speed with which we can solve problems when they're oriented around wealth, when they're oriented around business,\" said state Rep. Jason Probst, a Democrat from central Kansas.\n\nYet Probst voted for the bill.\n\n\"This is the system that we're stuck in, so if we choose to opt out of that system, we will lose every time,\" he said.\n\nEconomists who study pro sports teams have concluded in dozens of studies that a new stadium and shopping-and-entertainment area merely takes existing economic activity away from elsewhere in a community, resulting in little or no net gain.\n\n\"It could still help Kansas and maybe hurt Missouri by the same amount,\" said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith college in central Massachusetts who has written multiple books about sports. \"It's a zero-sum game.\"\n\nA skeptical state Sen. Molly Baumgardner, a Kansas City-area Republican, used a Christmas Eve metaphor to characterize supporters' excitement before she voted no.\n\n\"There are visions of sugar plums,\" Baumgardner said.", {"uri": "2024-06-395092219", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "19:19:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T19:19:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:47:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://internewscast.com/local-news/understanding-the-kansas-city-chiefs-missouri-mayor-discusses-jobs-battle/", "title": "Understanding the Kansas City Chiefs: Missouri Mayor Discusses Jobs Battle - Internewscast Journal", "body": "TOPEKA, Kan. - A plan in Kansas for luring the Kansas City's two major league sports franchises from Missouri has prompted their hometown's mayor to declare that the move ends a 5-year-old agreement by the states not to poach each other's jobs.\n\nThe Kansas Legislature has approved a measure to allow the state to issue bonds to help the Super Bowl Champion Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Royals pay for new stadiums in Kansas. It goes next to Gov. Laura Kelly.\n\nHere are a few things to know about the two states' contest for the teams.\n\nKansas is poised to make offers\n\nWhile Kelly has not formally pledged to sign the stadium-financing bill, she issued a positive statement when it passed Tuesday, saying it could make Kansas \"a professional sports powerhouse.\" If she signs it, as many lawmakers expect, it would take effect July 1.\n\nThe state's secretary of commerce, Lt. Gov. David Toland, would negotiate with one or both teams on a plan for a new stadium. Kelly and eight top legislative leaders would have to approve each deal with a vote in a public meeting.\n\nA deal would draw the boundaries of a district around a stadium and possibly another around a separate practice facility, and new state sales and alcohol tax revenues generated by shops, restaurants, bars and hotels within that district would pay off the bonds over 30 years.\n\nThe city and county could pledge tax revenues as well but are not required to do so, and the state also could use revenues from sports betting and state lottery ticket sales to back bonds as well.\n\nThe bonds could cover up to 70% of the costs of the new stadiums, though supporters of the plan don't expect that, anticipating that two stadiums together could cost $4 billion.\n\nThere is talk of a renewed economic 'border war'\n\nThe Kansas-Missouri border splits the 2.3 million-resident Kansas City area, and there's both Kansas City, Missouri, and Kansas City, Kansas. Much of the border is the median of State Line Road, and about 60% of the area's residents live on the Missouri side.\n\nA feud between the two states has existed for generations and most recently saw each state burning through tens of millions of dollars in subsides to pull existing businesses across the border. Officials on both sides came to see the contest as expensive and wasteful, and in 2019, Kelly, a Democrat, and Missouri Gov. Mike Parson, a Republican, signed a truce.\n\nKansas City, Missouri Mayor Quinton Lucas told reporters that Kansas' bid for the Chiefs and Royals restarted that economic \"border war.\"\n\n\"I do believe long-term that we're one place and it's better when we work together,\" he said during a news conference.\n\nBut Kelly doesn't agree that the states' truce has been violated, telling reporters this week that before the agreement, \"We never discussed the teams.\"\n\nKansas lawmakers tapped fears about the future\n\nKansas lawmakers acted after voters on the Missouri side refused in April to extend a local sales tax for keeping up the complex with the teams' side-by-side stadiums. Many Kansas lawmakers worried that if they didn't act, the teams might move out of the area altogether -- mentioning Salt Lake City, San Antonio and Nashville.\n\nSeveral economists who've studied professional sports were dubious that moving would make financial sense for either team -- especially the Chiefs, who have a rabid fan base that could be hard to build quickly elsewhere. In addition, after pro football's Rams moved nearly a decade ago from St. Louis to Los Angeles, the team's owner and the National Football League paid $790 million to settle a lawsuit filed by St. Louis interests.\n\nBut Kansas lawmakers noted that the Royals' major-league predecessor, the Athletics, moved to Oakland, California, in 1968 and now plan to relocate to Las Vegas. Kansas City lost major-league professional teams to other cities in the 1970s and 1980s, and the Chiefs came to Kansas City in 1963 after starting as the Dallas Texans four years earlier.\n\n\"The state of Missouri is known for losing professional teams,\" Kansas state Rep. Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican, who helped lead the push for the stadium bill.\n\nKansas officials expect Missouri to respond\n\nMissouri officials have pledged to do what it takes to keep the Chiefs and Royals in their state but have not outlined specific proposals. Lucas saw the April vote as a sign that area residents wanted officials to discuss options other than extending the sales tax.\n\nLike their counterparts in Kansas, Missouri lawmakers have finished their annual regular session, but they are set to meet again Sept. 11 to consider vetoes by Parson.\n\nSupporters of Kansas' bid for the teams said it could spur an aggressive response from Missouri -- and added that if the teams get offers they like and opt to stay there, at least they're still in the Kansas City area.\n\nLucas said the teams now have \"exceptional leverage.\"\n\nKansas and Missouri describe the timeline differently\n\nBackers of the Kansas bid said such comments justified acting Tuesday, during a one-day special session that Kelly called to consider tax cuts after lawmakers adjourned their regular annual session May 1. Some critics argued that legislators should have waited until their regular 2025 session starts in January so a plan could be properly vetted.\n\nBut Parson and Lucas have said the contest for the teams is only in its \"first quarter,\" using a football metaphor.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Summer Ballentine, in Columbia, Missouri, and Jim Salter, in O'Fallon, Missouri, also contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City_Chiefs", {"uri": "2024-06-392802620", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "23:21:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T23:21:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T23:10:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.kmbc.com/article/supporters-opponents-on-proposal-to-bring-chiefs-and-royals-to-kansas/61147940", "title": "Supporters, opponents sound off on proposal to bring Chiefs and Royals to Kansas", "body": "Supporters and opponents of a proposal to bring the Chiefs and Royals to Kansas had their say at the state capital in Topeka on Monday.It happened at a joint Kansas House and Senate Commerce Committee meeting.\"It's such an exciting thing for our state. Probably the largest economic development deal we possibly could have,\" said Ron Ryckman.Ryckman, the former Kansas House Speaker, is currently behind a public education initiative from a non-profit group called \"Scoop and Score.\" The group had collected more than 11,000 petition signatures as of Monday.Ryckman is also a registered lobbyist for the Chiefs.\"As a Chiefs fan, I can't be more excited. You know, a couple of years ago, we kind of forecast this to be a possibility. When we established the fund inside the sports betting fund to allow likes to happen, we wanted to kind of set the marker and say, hey, we're interested and just waiting for the opportunity. And, of course, here's our opportunity to bring the Chiefs and possibly the Royals to Kansas,\" he said.The plan calls for lawmakers to approve sales tax or STAR bonds to partially subsidize construction of new stadiums with the teams and other private businesses paying for the rest of it.STAR bonds have a bond company loan money, and sales taxes on items like tickets, concessions, and hotel stays in a given area are used to make payments on those bonds.Dave Trabert of the conservative-leaning Kansas Policy Institute spoke against the plan Monday. \"First of all, there's a long history of stadium subsidies not working. There's always a lot of optimistic projections. But the research, even from the left-leaning Brookings Institute, shows that these projects are not successful. Part of the reason for that is that subsidies most often just move economic activity,\" Trabert said.Leaders of the Kansas Legislature pushed to get this measure introduced at Tuesday's special session.They hope to get it approved and move forward in a single day.\"I think it's not the way that legislation should be done. There should be careful study. There should be committee hearings, not just one informational hearing. We still haven't seen the bill,\" Trabert said.Kansas Governor Laura Kelly called Tuesday's special session to get a tax relief measure passed.After two years of haggling, the governor and leaders of the legislature reached a deal on Thursday.On Monday, Governor Kelly weighed on the push for the Chiefs and Royals to use STAR bonds.\"The beauty of STAR bonds is that while it does capture tax revenue, it's tax revenue that would not have been there in the first place. And then also, those bonds are not a risk for the state. The bond purchasers carry that risk. So, it's about the only way they could consider doing this,\" she said.Artist renderings of a new domed stadium for the Chiefs in Kansas City, Kansas, are already available.Leaders of that community say there's also plenty of options for the Royals, including along the Missouri or Kansas River overlooking both downtown Kansas City, Missouri and downtown Kansas City, Kansas.The Royals have also hired lobbyists to represent them in Kansas.\n\nSupporters and opponents of a proposal to bring the Chiefs and Royals to Kansas had their say at the state capital in Topeka on Monday.\n\nIt happened at a joint Kansas House and Senate Commerce Committee meeting.\n\n\"It's such an exciting thing for our state. Probably the largest economic development deal we possibly could have,\" said Ron Ryckman.\n\nRyckman, the former Kansas House Speaker, is currently behind a public education initiative from a non-profit group called \"Scoop and Score.\"\n\nThe group had collected more than 11,000 petition signatures as of Monday.\n\nRyckman is also a registered lobbyist for the Chiefs.\n\n\"As a Chiefs fan, I can't be more excited. You know, a couple of years ago, we kind of forecast this to be a possibility. When we established the fund inside the sports betting fund to allow likes to happen, we wanted to kind of set the marker and say, hey, we're interested and just waiting for the opportunity. And, of course, here's our opportunity to bring the Chiefs and possibly the Royals to Kansas,\" he said.\n\nThe plan calls for lawmakers to approve sales tax or STAR bonds to partially subsidize construction of new stadiums with the teams and other private businesses paying for the rest of it.\n\nSTAR bonds have a bond company loan money, and sales taxes on items like tickets, concessions, and hotel stays in a given area are used to make payments on those bonds.\n\nDave Trabert of the conservative-leaning Kansas Policy Institute spoke against the plan Monday.\n\n\"First of all, there's a long history of stadium subsidies not working. There's always a lot of optimistic projections. But the research, even from the left-leaning Brookings Institute, shows that these projects are not successful. Part of the reason for that is that subsidies most often just move economic activity,\" Trabert said.\n\nLeaders of the Kansas Legislature pushed to get this measure introduced at Tuesday's special session.\n\nThey hope to get it approved and move forward in a single day.\n\n\"I think it's not the way that legislation should be done. There should be careful study. There should be committee hearings, not just one informational hearing. We still haven't seen the bill,\" Trabert said.\n\nKansas Governor Laura Kelly called Tuesday's special session to get a tax relief measure passed.\n\nAfter two years of haggling, the governor and leaders of the legislature reached a deal on Thursday.\n\nOn Monday, Governor Kelly weighed on the push for the Chiefs and Royals to use STAR bonds.\n\n\"The beauty of STAR bonds is that while it does capture tax revenue, it's tax revenue that would not have been there in the first place. And then also, those bonds are not a risk for the state. The bond purchasers carry that risk. So, it's about the only way they could consider doing this,\" she said.\n\nArtist renderings of a new domed stadium for the Chiefs in Kansas City, Kansas, are already available.\n\nLeaders of that community say there's also plenty of options for the Royals, including along the Missouri or Kansas River overlooking both downtown Kansas City, Missouri and downtown Kansas City, Kansas.\n\nThe {"uri": "8183304693", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "09:30:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T09:30:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T09:30:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.ksal.com/chiefs-royals-open-to-moving-to-kansas/", "title": "Chiefs, Royals Open to Moving to Kansas", "body": "Representatives of the Kansas City Chiefs and Royals urged Kansas lawmakers Monday to expand a tax incentive program to provide the teams millions of dollars to leave Missouri and set up shop in new stadiums across the state line.\n\n\"If we want to be major league we've got to have major league teams,\" Korb Maxwell, an attorney who represents the Chiefs, told lawmakers during an informational hearing at the Kansas Statehouse. \"This is the greatest opportunity we've had in any generation, and it's here before us right now.\"\n\nOther proponents of the plan were more blunt: If Kansas doesn't act, a group hoping to lure the teams to Kansas argued, the Kansas City region is at risk of losing its professional football and baseball teams.\n\n\"The risk that the Kansas City Chiefs and the Kansas City Royals -- our Chiefs, our Royals -- could be lured away by other states is not a risk that Kansans want to take,\" said Dan Murray, a lobbyist for Scoop and Score Inc., a nonprofit hoping to bring the Chiefs to Kansas.\n\nOn the table Monday was a plan to expand the state's tax incentive program meant to help finance tourism and entertainment destinations. Under the legislation, the teams could receive more than $750 million to help finance stadium projects.\n\nThe informational hearing came ahead of a special legislative session that starts Tuesday. Lawmakers can't take action on the bill until the formal start of the special session.\n\nThe legislation would enhance the state's existing Sales Tax and Revenue (STAR) Bond program to provide up to 75% of the project's costs by issuing bonds that would be repaid with the increased sales state tax collections at the project site. Other projects can use STAR Bonds to finance up to 50% of a project.\n\nThe bill requires a minimum $1 billion capital investment and limits the eligibility to National Football League or Major League Baseball teams currently located near Kansas. The financing mechanism could be used for both stadiums and training facilities.\n\nDebt on a stadium constructed under the expansion wouldn't have to be repaid for 30 years instead of the normal 20.\n\nThe project could also receive a boost from liquor taxes generated in the STAR Bond district and revenues from a fund Kansas created when it legalized sports betting.\n\nGov. Laura Kelly, who has championed enormous economic development projects in Kansas, didn't commit to supporting the legislation on Monday.\n\n\"I'm impressed by the full-court press that has been made to get these teams to consider moving across the river,\" she told reporters. \"It's not something I'm going to invest a lot of energy in. I think this is something for the legislature to work through.\"\n\nKelly's chief of staff, Will Lawrence, told the joint committee the governor's office had no concerns with the current version of the bill that would keep her from signing it.\n\nSTAR Bonds have been criticized by some legislators as ineffective, and an audit found that less than one-quarter of the attractions funded through the program met the state's goal of increasing tourism. There may be some cases, the audit says, where certain projects kept Kansans spending money in Kansas rather than going to Missouri.\n\n\"But we think it's more often that local visitors simply move existing economic activity from one part of Kansas to another,\" the audit says.\n\nKansas lawmakers launched an effort to lure the Chiefs or Royals -- or both -- after Jackson County, Missouri, voters in April rejected a proposed extension of a 3/8-cent sales tax to help finance a new stadium for the Royals and upgrades at Arrowhead Stadium.\n\nMaxwell said the organization had been asked why the legislation needed to be passed in special session rather than when lawmakers reconvene for their normal session in January.\n\nBecause with only a few years left in the Chiefs' lease at Arrowhead, \"time is of the essence,\" he said.\n\n\"The time is now,\" Maxwell said. \"Missouri spoke, Jackson County spoke. They had their opportunity, but now there's a moment for Kansas to step up.\"\n\nThe effort to reauthorize the sales tax in Missouri was driven primarily by the Royals, whose executives unveiled plans to move to the Crossroads Arts District in downtown Kansas City in February -- less than two months before the vote. It failed with 58% of voters rejecting the proposal.\n\nEarlier this month, Scoop and Score Inc. launched to advocate for moving Chiefs -- the reigning Super Bowl champions -- to Kansas. The organization's website implores visitors to sign a petition to \"tell legislators to keep the Chiefs in KC!\"\n\nThe organization has hired 30 lobbyists, including Murray. The Royals have eight lobbyists, and the Chiefs employ former Kansas House Speaker Ron Ryckman Jr. and his former aide, Paje Resner, as lobbyists.\n\nRyckman said Kansas City Chiefs owner Clark Hunt could be open to moving the team outside of the Kansas City region.\n\n\"We're aware of numerous cities that would love to be the home of the Chiefs or the Royals,\" Ryckman said.\n\nMurray urged lawmakers to support the legislation, arguing it has \"guardrails, guardrails guardrails\" to keep the state and local governments from being on the hook for the bonds.\n\nWhile an attorney for the Chiefs acknowledged the franchise hasn't come up with a design or plan for a stadium in Kansas, Murray urged lawmakers to move forward with creating a program. Vetting the details, he said, will be up to the Kansas Department of Commerce with final approval by the Legislative Coordinating Council, an eight-member committee of House and Senate lawmakers that can adopt legislation when the Legislature is not in session.\n\nBut a draft of the bill says any agreement between the state and a team would be confidential until after it has been executed.\n\nThe bill was panned by libertarian groups as a handout for corporations that would do little to increase economic activity in Kansas. Dave Trabert, CEO of the Kansas Policy Institute, told the committee there was no way to verify the claims that the stadiums would boost the economy.\n\n\"We asked Scoop and Score to provide their math. 'Show us how you arrived at a billion dollars of economic activity,'' Trabert said. \"Nothing was forthcoming.\"\n\nIn an interview, Trabert called the proposal \"absurd.\"\n\n\"This isn't about economic development,\" he said. \"It's about politics. It's so people can say, 'Look what I did. Vote for me.'\u2009\"", "source": {"uri": "ksal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsRadio 1150 KSAL"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special_session", "type": {"uri": "8184084244", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "18:08:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T18:08:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T18:07:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/article/0bc5f4e1ea6a9387a0a34df23a1488e5/kansas-lawmakers-have-passed-tax-cuts-clear-way-plan-lure", "title": "Kansas lawmakers have passed tax cuts to clear the way for a plan to lure the Chiefs", "body": "TOPEKA, Kan. (AP) -- Kansas legislators cleared the way Tuesday for a debate on trying to lure the Kansas City Chiefs from Missouri by approving broad tax cuts that many lawmakers said they needed to see before considering a plan to help the Super Bowl champions finance a new stadium.\n\nThe Legislature took up the stadium proposal during a special session that convened Tuesday amid heavy lobbying for the plan. The measure would allow the state to issue bonds to help the Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Kansas City Royals finance new stadiums on the Kansas side of their metropolitan area, which is split by the border with Missouri.\n\nBut top Republicans in the GOP-controlled Legislature promised that the stadium proposal wouldn't be debated until the Legislature approved a plan that would cut income and property taxes by a total of $1.23 billion over the next three years. Many lawmakers argued that voters would be angry if the state helped finance new stadiums without cutting taxes.\n\n\"We definitely need to demonstrate that we're getting relief to our citizens,\" said Senate President Ty Masterson, a Wichita-area Republican who backed the stadium-financing plan.\n\nDemocratic Gov. Laura Kelly called the special session to have lawmakers consider reducing taxes after she vetoed three tax-cutting plans before legislators adjourned their regular annual session May 1. The plan lawmakers approved was a compromise between her and Republican leaders.\n\nLegislators made no changes in the plan before passing it, 34-4 in the Senate and 121-2 in the House. Kelly pledged to sign the measure into law.\n\nOnce legislators convened the special session, Kelly couldn't control what they considered, and that created an opening to consider the stadium-financing plan. That measure would use revenues from sports betting, the state lottery and new taxes raised from the area around each new stadium to pay off the state's bonds over 30 years.\n\nThe first version of the stadium-financing plan emerged in late April, but lawmakers didn't vote on it before adjourning. It would have allowed state bonds to finance all stadium construction costs, but the version to be considered by lawmakers Tuesday would cap the amount at 70% and require legislative leaders and the governor to sign off on any bonding plan.\n\nHouse Commerce Committee Chair Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican, said the Chiefs are likely to spend between $500 million and $700 million in private funds on a new stadium.\n\n\"There are no blank checks,\" Tarwater told GOP colleagues during a briefing on the plan before the House began debating it.\n\nA new nonprofit group, Scoop and Score, formed last month to push for bringing the Chiefs to Kansas, and that group and the Royals together hired more than 30 lobbyists for the special session. But the national free-market, small-government group Americans for Prosperity and the Kansas Policy Institute, a free-market think tank, oppose the measure, and both have been influential with conservative Republicans.\n\nFree-market conservatives have long opposed state and local subsidies for specific businesses or projects. And economists who've studied pro sports teams have concluded in dozens of studies over decades that subsidizing their stadiums isn't worth the cost.\n\n\"Most of the money that gets spent on the Chiefs is money that would otherwise be spent on other entertainment projects,\" said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College in central Massachusetts who has written multiple books about sports.\n\nKansas legislators consider the Chiefs and Royals in play because in April, voters on the Missouri side of the metro area refused to continue a local sales tax for the upkeep of the complex with their side-by-side stadiums. Missouri officials have said they'll do whatever it takes to keep the teams but haven't outlined any proposals.\n\nThe two teams' lease on their stadium complex runs through January 2031, but Korb Maxwell, an attorney for the Chiefs who lives on the Kansas side, said renovations on the team's Arrowhead Stadium should be planned seven or eight years in advance.\n\n\"There is an urgency to this,\" added David Frantz, the Royals' general counsel.\n\nSupporters of the stadium plan argued that economists' past research doesn't apply to the Chiefs and Royals. They said the bonds will be paid off with tax revenues that aren't being generated now and would never be without the stadiums or the development around them. Masterson said it's wrong to call the bonds a subsidy.\n\nAnd Maxwell said: \"For a town to be major league, they need major league teams.\"\n\nBut economists who've studied pro sports said similar arguments have been a staple of past debates over paying for new stadiums. Development around a new stadium lessens development elsewhere, where the tax dollars generated would go to fund services or schools, they said.\n\n\"It could still help Kansas and maybe hurt Missouri by the same amount,\" Zimbalist said. \"It's a zero-sum game.\"", "source": {"uri": "hosted.ap.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Associated Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8185785957", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:21:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:21:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:19:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.daytondailynews.com/nation-world/a-missouri-mayor-says-a-fight-over-jobs-is-back-on-things-to-know-about-kansas-wooing-the-chiefs/T754YQEYORGQPIC67FGKBVZ7UA/", "title": "A Missouri mayor says a fight over jobs is back on. Things to know about Kansas wooing the Chiefs", "body": "The Kansas Legislature has approved a measure to allow the state to issue bonds to help the Super Bowl Champion Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Royals pay for new stadiums in Kansas. It goes next to Gov. Laura Kelly.\n\nHere are a few things to know about the two states' contest for the teams.\n\nWhile Kelly has not formally pledged to sign the stadium-financing bill, she issued a positive statement when it passed Tuesday, saying it could make Kansas \"a professional sports powerhouse.\" If she signs it, as many lawmakers expect, it would take effect July 1.\n\nThe state's secretary of commerce, Lt. Gov. David Toland, would negotiate with one or both teams on a plan for a new stadium. Kelly and eight top legislative leaders would have to approve each deal with a vote in a public meeting.\n\nA deal would draw the boundaries of a district around a stadium and possibly another around a separate practice facility, and new state sales and alcohol tax revenues generated by shops, restaurants, bars and hotels within that district would pay off the bonds over 30 years.\n\nThe city and county could pledge tax revenues as well but are not required to do so, and the state also could use revenues from sports betting and state lottery ticket sales to back bonds as well.\n\nThe bonds could cover up to 70% of the costs of the new stadiums, though supporters of the plan don't expect that, anticipating that two stadiums together could cost $4 billion.\n\nThe Kansas-Missouri border splits the 2.3 million-resident Kansas City area, and there's both Kansas City, Missouri, and Kansas City, Kansas. Much of the border is the median of State Line Road, and about 60% of the area's residents live on the Missouri side.\n\nA feud between the two states has existed for generations and most recently saw each state burning through tens of millions of dollars in subsides to pull existing businesses across the border. Officials on both sides came to see the contest as expensive and wasteful, and in 2019, Kelly, a Democrat, and Missouri Gov. Mike Parson, a Republican, signed a truce.\n\nKansas City, Missouri Mayor Quinton Lucas told reporters that Kansas' bid for the Chiefs and Royals restarted that economic \"border war.\"\n\n\"I do believe long-term that we're one place and it's better when we work together,\" he said during a news conference.\n\nBut Kelly doesn't agree that the states' truce has been violated, telling reporters this week that before the agreement, \"We never discussed the teams.\"\n\nKansas lawmakers acted after voters on the Missouri side refused in April to extend a local sales tax for keeping up the complex with the teams' side-by-side stadiums. Many Kansas lawmakers worried that if they didn't act, the teams might move out of the area altogether -- mentioning Salt Lake City, San Antonio and Nashville.\n\nSeveral economists who've studied professional sports were dubious that moving would make financial sense for either team -- especially the Chiefs, who have a rabid fan base that could be hard to build quickly elsewhere. In addition, after pro football's Rams moved nearly a decade ago from St. Louis to Los Angeles, the team's owner and the National Football League paid $790 million to settle a lawsuit filed by St. Louis interests.\n\nBut Kansas lawmakers noted that the Royals' major-league predecessor, the Athletics, moved to Oakland, California, in 1968 and now plan to relocate to Las Vegas. Kansas City lost major-league professional teams to other cities in the 1970s and 1980s, and the Chiefs came to Kansas City in 1963 after starting as the Dallas Texans four years earlier.\n\n\"The state of Missouri is known for losing professional teams,\" Kansas state Rep. Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican, who helped lead the push for the stadium bill.\n\nMissouri officials have pledged to do what it takes to keep the Chiefs and Royals in their state but have not outlined specific proposals. Lucas saw the April vote as a sign that area residents wanted officials to discuss options other than extending the sales tax.\n\nLike their counterparts in Kansas, Missouri lawmakers have finished their annual regular session, but they are set to meet again Sept. 11 to consider vetoes by Parson.\n\nSupporters of Kansas' bid for the teams said it could spur an aggressive response from Missouri -- and added that if the teams get offers they like and opt to stay there, at least they're still in the Kansas City area.\n\nLucas said the teams now have \"exceptional leverage.\"\n\nThe lease on the complex with the Chiefs' and Royals' existing stadiums runs through January 2031, but the teams have said they must plan renovations or new stadiums years in advance for them to be ready on time. Both suggested that even seven years out, time for a decision is short.\n\nBackers of the Kansas bid said such comments justified acting Tuesday, during a one-day special session that Kelly called to consider tax cuts after lawmakers adjourned their regular annual session May 1. Some critics argued that legislators should have waited until their regular 2025 session starts in January so a plan could be properly vetted.\n\nBut Parson and Lucas have said the contest for the teams is only in its \"first quarter,\" using a football metaphor.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writers Summer Ballentine, in Columbia, Missouri, and Jim Salter, in O'Fallon, Missouri, also contributed to this story.", "source": {"uri": "daytondailynews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Dayton Daily News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City_Chiefs", {"uri": "8187364399", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:23:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:23:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:12:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/missouri-lawmakers-criticize-kansas-attempt-160455989.html", "title": "Missouri lawmakers criticize Kansas attempt to poach Royals, Chiefs", "body": "Fireworks go off before a game at GEHA Field at Arrowhead Stadium in Kansas City, Missouri last September. Kansas lawmakers passed legislation that would offer incentives if the Kansas City Chiefs relocate from Arrowhead to Kansas and build a new stadium (David Eulitt/Getty Images).\n\nState and local officials from Missouri denounced Kansas legislators' attempt to lure the Kansas City Chiefs and Royals across the state line, saying they would take steps to keep both teams.\n\nKansas City Mayor Quinton Lucas, in a statement on Tuesday, said the city and state would continue negotiations with the teams that Missouri and Kansas City have \"welcomed, funded and supported ... since the 1960s.\"\n\n\"We remain in the first quarter of the Kansas City stadium discussion,\" Lucas said.\n\nKansas lawmakers on Tuesday passed legislation meant to help finance new stadiums for the Kansas City Chiefs and Royals in an attempt to relocate one or both teams from Missouri. The legislation, an expansion of the state's existing Sales Tax and Revenue (STAR) Bond program, could yield hundreds of millions of dollars for each stadium.\n\nIt comes after Jackson County, Missouri, voters in April rejected the extension of a sales tax to help finance a new downtown Kansas City baseball stadium for the Royals and upgrades to the Chiefs' Arrowhead Stadium.\n\nKansas lawmakers who supported the STAR Bond legislation said it was necessary to keep the teams in the Kansas City area.\n\n\"We're in jeopardy of Kansas City losing those franchises,\" Kansas Sen. Jeff Pittman, a Leavenworth Democrat, said during debate on the bill Tuesday. \"Missouri has dropped the ball. We now have an opportunity to make an offer.\"\n\nAfter Kansas lawmakers' vote, Missouri legislators said they hoped and expected to see the state put forward a plan.\n\n\"It's a wakeup call to Missouri that there are other states that are willing to do whatever it takes to get the teams,\" Missouri House Majority Leader Jonathan Patterson, a Lee's Summit Republican, said in an interview Thursday.\n\nPatterson, who is in line to become speaker of the House next year, said he expected to see Missouri put together a plan after this summer's primary elections and before the Missouri General Assembly returns for its legislative session in January. He said it was possible legislators would be called back to Jefferson City for a special session but didn't think it was necessary.\n\nThe Kansas legislation would help finance up to 70% of a stadium project -- with a minimum $1 billion price tag and 30,000 seats -- by issuing bonds to be repaid with the state sales tax collected in the STAR Bond district. Liquor taxes from the district and funds from the state's legalization of sports betting also could be used to repay the bonds.\n\nThe offer remains in place for a year and is limited to National Football League or Major League Baseball teams in states adjacent to Kansas.\n\nKansas' attempt to poach the teams was seen by several Missouri lawmakers as a violation of a truce the two states reached five years ago to stop offering incentives to move businesses back and forth the state line in the Kansas City area.\n\nBut Kansas Gov. Laura Kelly, a Democrat, didn't see it that way.\n\n\"The border war was really focused on businesses like AMC Theatres, which went back and forth, back and forth,\" Kelly said. \"We never discussed teams.\"\n\nFor years, the two states engaged in an economic development \"border war,\" offering incentives to companies that jumped the state line, spending taxpayer funds while largely not creating any new jobs.\n\n\"Today's vote regrettably restarts the Missouri-Kansas incentive border war, creating leverage for the teams, but injecting even greater uncertainty into the regional stadium conversation,\" Lucas said Tuesday.\n\nIn a statement Tuesday, Jackson County, Missouri, Executive Frank White Jr. urged state and local governments to abide by the border war truce \"and refrain from engaging in a counterproductive stadium bidding war.\"\n\n\"We must focus on common sense over politics,\" White said. \"Our resources should be used wisely to improve the lives of our residents, not wasted on bidding wars that only serve to drain public funds and divide our region.\"\n\nWhite said in order to agree to subsidies for a stadium he expects \"a complete and transparent plan that offers tangible benefits to our taxpayers.\"\n\n\"My office remains open to conversations with the Royals, Chiefs, lawmakers, and other stakeholders, but any proposal must meet this standard and make sense for our community,\" he said.\n\nMissouri Sen. Denny Hoskins, a Warrensburg Republican, said the border war \"didn't benefit anyone\" and saw Kansas' push to relocate the teams as a violation.\n\nHe said he wanted to see the Missouri Department of Economic Development make an offer to keep the teams, but he didn't support the idea of lawmakers being called back to Jefferson City for a special session and didn't want a package that could put taxpayers on the hook.\n\n\"We want to keep the Kansas City Chiefs and KC Royals in the state of Missouri, but we can't saddle taxpayers with billions of dollars in debt to help finance stadiums,\" he said.\n\nHoskins, who is running in the GOP primary for secretary of state, said he thought the Kansas plan was based on lofty revenue expectations and that the stadiums wouldn't generate enough activity to pay off the bonds without additional assistance from Kansas taxpayers. He didn't want to see Missouri put forward a similar plan.\n\n\"Missouri taxpayers shouldn't be on the hook for financing stadiums for billion-dollar corporations and multimillion-dollar athletes,\" he said. \"It's hard enough being a Missourian right now just trying to keep your own money in your pocket, let alone financing stadiums for a billion-dollar industry.\"\n\nPatterson called the border war talk \"somewhat irrelevant.\"", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arrowhead_Stadium", "type":
