{"uri": "2024-06-393914455", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "20:16:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T20:16:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T19:12:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/kansas-lawmakers-pass-tax-cuts-have-eyes-on-chiefs/article_181698ac-7910-59ec-ae56-4ed9c46d1681.html", "title": "Kansas lawmakers pass tax cuts, have eyes on Chiefs", "body": "ASSOCIATED PRESS\n\nTOPEKA, Kan. -- Kansas legislators cleared the way Tuesday for a debate on trying to lure the Kansas City Chiefs from Missouri by approving broad tax cuts that many lawmakers said they needed to see before considering a plan to help the Super Bowl champions finance a new stadium.\n\nThe Legislature took up the stadium proposal during a special session that convened Tuesday amid heavy lobbying for the plan. The measure would allow the state to issue bonds to help the Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Kansas City Royals finance new stadiums on the Kansas side of their metropolitan area, which is split by the border with Missouri.\n\nBut top Republicans in the GOP-controlled Legislature promised that the stadium proposal wouldn't be debated until the Legislature approved a plan that would cut income and property taxes by a total of $1.23 billion over the next three years. Many lawmakers argued that voters would be angry if the state helped finance new stadiums without cutting taxes.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nFormer Sioux City hotel under renovation, to become high-rise senior housing this year Lost and found: How Arnolds Park got a miniature train back after more than 50 years Jefferson, S.D. dad shares secret to fatherhood on Father's Day celebration Perley to step down as Thompson CEO; Beaulieu to take over Man charged with stabbing at Sioux City hotel Sioux City Marina operator countersues city over lease dispute Omaha ballpark seeks to ban two Texas A&M fans who were kicked out of College World Series game Athlete of the Week: Miller's motor leading the way for West Monona Le Mars man arrested after standoff for breaking woman's nose Tyson Foods heir suspended as CFO after second alcohol-related arrest Our Opinion: WITCC settlement in human trafficking case raises more questions Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for June 17, 2024 Inclusive Sioux City Advisory Committee has lost members since Ghebrekidan suspension, termination Chainsaw sculptures among latest upgrades to Sioux City's historic Hubbard Park Elk Creek Road construction project begins next week\n\n\"We definitely need to demonstrate that we're getting relief to our citizens,\" said Senate President Ty Masterson, a Wichita-area Republican who backed the stadium-financing plan.\n\nDemocratic Gov. Laura Kelly called the special session to have lawmakers consider reducing taxes after she vetoed three tax-cutting plans before legislators adjourned their regular annual session May 1. The plan lawmakers approved was a compromise between her and Republican leaders.\n\nLegislators made no changes in the plan before passing it, 34-4 in the Senate and 121-2 in the House. Kelly pledged to sign the measure into law.\n\nOnce legislators convened the special session, Kelly couldn't control what they considered, and that created an opening to consider the stadium-financing plan. That measure would use revenues from sports betting, the state lottery and new taxes raised from the area around each new stadium to pay off the state's bonds over 30 years.\n\nThe first version of the stadium-financing plan emerged in late April, but lawmakers didn't vote on it before adjourning. It would have allowed state bonds to finance all stadium construction costs, but the version to be considered by lawmakers Tuesday would cap the amount at 70% and require legislative leaders and the governor to sign off on any bonding plan.\n\nHouse Commerce Committee Chair Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican, said the Chiefs are likely to spend between $500 million and $700 million in private funds on a new stadium.\n\nBRIEFLY\n\nLIONS: Detroit signed all-United Football League kicker Jake Bates, who made three field goals from at least 60 yards for the Michigan Panthers this past season. Detroit added depth at a position with veteran Michael Badgley.\n\nBEARS: Chicago signed veteran receiver and return specialist DeAndre Carter to a one-year contract. The 31-year-old Carter has 108 receptions for 1,259 yards and six touchdowns over six seasons with Philadelphia, Houston, Chicago, Washington, the Los Angeles Chargers and Las Vegas {"uri": "8185560374", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:22:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:22:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:22:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://fox2now.com/sports/kansas-city-chiefs/kansas-lawmakers-pass-bill-to-lure-chiefs-royals-from-missouri/", "title": "Kansas lawmakers pass bill to lure Chiefs, Royals from Missouri", "body": "TOPEKA, Kan. - The Kansas House and Senate overwhelmingly passed the STAR bond legislation that was put up for a vote on both floors - the idea to lure the Chiefs and the Royals across the state line.\n\n\"The state of Missouri is known for losing professional teams - not too long ago they just lost the St. Louis Rams, they used to have a professional hockey team the Scouts, they're gone, they had the Kansas City Kings, they're gone, so I ask you today, do you really want to put that kind of economic generation in the hands of the state of Missouri?\" Rep. Sean Tarwater, (R-Kan.) who carried the bill, said on the House floor.\n\nWith the passage of this bill, the state of Kansas could pay for up to 70% of the cost of the stadium project.\n\nThe bonds would be paid back over a thirty-year period from new sales taxes created in the district, liquor taxes in the district, and money generated by a sports wagering fund. Cities and counties could participate in the district, or opt out.\n\nThe district would be determined by the secretary of commerce as part of negotiations.\n\nPeople on the \"no side of this are clear, this is too big of a risk, there is not enough information as to the benefit this would have and if in the end it would hurt Kansas tax payers.\n\n\"I couldn't ensure myself that the tax payers that I represent wouldn't ultimately be on the hook if this didn't work out. I think we do need more time. I don't know what the rush is, they say it has to be done yesterday a lot of us - somebody is going to be back here in 6 months and why can't we spend the first week of our return if this is that important to deal with it at that point,\" Rep. Bob Lewis (R-Kan.), who voted no said.\n\nBut nevertheless, that opposition never stood a chance. Both votes getting more than enough creating a super majority vote situation. The House voted 84-38 while the Senate was 27-8.\n\nThe importance of having the super majority support means that this is veto proof if Kansas Gov. Laura Kelly decided to do that.\n\nAlthough that would be a surprise because every indication given from her office indicates she will sign this into law once it makes it to her desk.\n\nThe Royals released the following statement Tuesday:\n\n\"We're grateful to the Kansas Legislature for today's bipartisan action that gives the state a pragmatic tool in which to achieve its economic development goals. The Kansas City Royals look forward to additional conversations as we evaluate where we will play baseball in the future. We will always prioritize the best interests of our fans, associates, and taxpayers in this process.\"\n\nThe Chiefs released the following statement as well Tuesday:\n\n\"We appreciate that leaders in the State of Kansas proactively reached out to us for input on the proposed STAR Bond legislation. We support their efforts to expand the existing program and congratulate them on passing the legislation in special session. {"uri": "8185725513", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "17:29:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T17:29:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T17:28:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/sports/kansas-lawmakers-take-pivotal-step-to-lure-chiefs-royals-from-missouri-5671260", "title": "Kansas Lawmakers Take Pivotal Step to Lure Chiefs, Royals From Missouri", "body": "Kansas Gov. Laura Kelly envisions the day when the state becomes a \"professional sports powerhouse.\"\n\nThe state's legislators are following her lead.\n\nMs. Kelly will now review the plan and is expected to approve the proposal for the new athletic sites.\n\n\"Kansas now has the opportunity to become a professional sports powerhouse with the Chiefs and Royals potentially joining Sporting KC as major league attractions, all with robust, revenue-generating entertainment districts surrounding them providing new jobs, new visitors, and new revenues that boost the Kansas economy,\" she added.\n\nWhile there is still much work and debate ahead to get final approval for the facilities, both the defending Super Bowl champion Chiefs and Royals appreciate that the Kansas lawmakers are considering new facilities.\n\nThe Chiefs currently play in GEHA Field at Arrowhead Stadium, which was opened in 1972 and lacks many of the amenities of some of the new state-of-the-art stadiums such as those in Dallas and Los Angeles.\n\nIn April, residents of Jackson County, Missouri, voted down a sales tax measure that would have helped fund a new downtown ballpark along with major renovations to Arrowhead Stadium. The Chiefs had committed $300 million in private money and would have used their share as part of the current stadium's proposed $800 million renovation.\n\nThis opened the door for a potential new home in Kansas.\n\nThe Royals are dealing with similar issues because they play at Kauffman Stadium, which opened in 1973. While it is one of the most scenic stadiums in Major League Baseball, with a fountain and waterfall display behind the right-field fence, the site also lacks modern amenities.\n\nThe Royals had pledged at least $1 billion from ownership for the renovations to Kauffman Stadium and wanted to use their share of the tax revenue to help fund a $2 billion-plus ballpark district. The Royals lease at the Truman Sports Complex runs through Jan. 31, 2031, and team officials have said they will not play at Kauffman Stadium beyond the 2030 season.\n\nNow, a move to Kansas is in the works, and the Royals are receptive to a new home.\n\nOther states have taken measures to ensure their professional sports teams stay in town.\n\nThe Ravens are allocating about $430 million of the $600 million of state funds for stadium improvements.\n\n\"M&T Bank Stadium is not just home to the Ravens, but it's an epicenter of excitement, opportunity, and Maryland pride. ... This renovation program positions M&T Bank Stadium as a venue that will continue to provide Ravens fans with one of the best game day experiences in all of sports, while also attracting world-class concerts and other live events to Maryland,\" she added.\n\nIn December, the Orioles agreed to a 30-year lease extension at Camden Yards. The team was sold to David Rubenstein and his ownership group in March for $1.725 billion. Mr. Rubenstein plans to use the $600 million in state funds for stadium renovations to revitalize the park.\n\nMarty Conway, an adjunct professor at Georgetown University who teaches courses in sports leadership, told The Epoch Times that the vote in the Kansas Legislature is a very preliminary move and signals their interest in negotiating a package for the teams. The most likely next step is for the public officials in Jackson County, where both teams currently play, to revisit their stadium funding capabilities, likely in the upcoming fall 2024 election cycle.\n\n\"Typically, those moves, or threats of a move, are over much larger distances, sometimes thousands of miles,\" Mr. Conway said. \"Currently, the Royals and Chiefs play their games approximately 20 miles from the border between Kansas and Missouri. A move of this type wouldn't disrupt the fan experience or opportunity, somewhat like the Atlanta Braves moving from Fulton County to Cobb County in 2017.\"\n\nMissouri Gov. Mike Parson plans to find ways to keep the Chiefs and Royals in the state, but more money and support is currently one state away in Kansas.", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", "dataType": Chiefs, Royals relocation", "body": "The Kansas City Chiefs may be on the fast track to relocate after recent Sunflower State developments.\n\nSince a ballot initiative to keep the Chiefs and Royals in Kansas City, Missouri failed earlier this year, legislators in Kansas were quick to do their part to bring the teams across State Line Road.\n\nOn Tuesday, the Kansas House of Representatives passed legislation to lure Kansas City's crown jewels across the border, marking an important step in their scheme to get the teams to relocate.\n\nAccording to Matt Evans of KMBC, the proposal will now head to the Kansas Senate, where lawmakers will vote to finalize the measure that passed in the House.\n\nWhile this isn't an indication that the teams are all-in on a move to Kansas, it certainly doesn't bode well for Jackson County, which seems closer to losing the Chiefs and Royals than ever.\n\nFans on both sides of the border were quick to react to the latest news from Topeka on Twitter, {"uri": "8182884556", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "04:18:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T04:18:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T04:18:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/tuesday-special-session-discuss-tax-015339197.html", "title": "Tuesday's special session to discuss new tax plan, package to lure professional team to Kansas", "body": "TOPEKA, Kan. (KSNW) -- A new tax plan is on the table for Kansas lawmakers, setting aside millions of dollars in tax relief, as well as a plan to lure the Kansas City Chiefs or Royals to Kansas.\n\nLawmakers wrapped up a round of informational hearings on Monday. It's starting to sound like a broken record with just how many tax plans we saw come up this session, but this seems to be one that everyone in leadership at least is signing on to, including the governor.\n\nIt's not that different from what we saw her strike down in April. This one still has some bipartisan perks, like cutting the Social Security and food tax. Still, it makes some minor adjustments to meet the \"affordability criteria\" from the governor, which means getting rid of some of the property tax relief. That's been a sore spot for some.\n\nWe could see this come up during the debate Tuesday. Lawmakers, though, get to keep the two-rate income tax system that some have been pushing for. It gets rid of the bottom bracket for low-income taxpayers.\n\nTax cuts could save Kansans $1.2B over 3 years\n\n\"The personal exemption for dependents increases from 2,250 to 2,320 for every dependent that you have. Then, we get rid of the bottom tax bracket, 3.1%. I think the calculation during the session was $31,000 and below will not be paying state income tax,\" said Senator Caryn Tyson (R), Senate Tax Chair.\n\nAccording to the senator, that's for a family of four. So, how much does this package cost?\n\nThat's been the biggest issue in this debate.\n\nFor perspective, the quote that came up on Monday was $471.6 million in fiscal year 2025.\n\nThat's about $128 million less than the package the governor vetoed would've cost for that fiscal year. We're told this package is going to be starting in the Senate.\n\nA plan to lure the Chiefs or Royals to Kansas is just hours away from going up for debate in Tuesday's special session of the legislature.\n\nIt's going to take a lot of money, and we're talking billions of dollars, to build a stadium for either team.\n\nThe bill will cover 70% percent of the cost, and the minimum capital investment would be $1 billion. In addition, it has a 30-year payback schedule.\n\nThe money would be paid back through 100% of the sales tax on alcohol sales made within the stadium district. That's along with the state revenue from sports gambling and lottery gaming.\n\nKansas committees meet over STAR bonds bill to lure Chiefs, Royals\n\nJust like the tax plan we've been tracking for the special session, cost has been a concern. Some groups arguing that the responsibility falls on the taxpayers.\n\n\"The bondholders themselves are the ones that are liable for the star bonds. The taxpayer is not liable for the star bonds,\" said Ron Ryckman, Scoop and Score.\n\n\"What I'm speaking of is the fact that it's a subsidy, which means taxpayers are paying for this, and as opposed to going to services that benefit everybody, it's going to one or possibly two out-of-state billionaires,\" said Michael Austin, AFP Kansas Legislative Director.\n\nIt's important to note that there is a provision in the bill that notes that the money will only come from those revenue streams that we mentioned as opposed to \"general state revenue.\" We're told that the plan is going to be starting off in the House.\n\nThe special session kicks off at 9 a.m. on Tuesday.\n\nCopyright 2024 Nexstar Media, Inc. {"uri": "8184400156", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:34:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:34:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:33:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/kansas-lawmakers-approve-a-plan-to-lure-the-chiefs-from-missouri-by-helping-to-finance/article_9c76287b-4b8f-51e1-9fa3-7b5278f3667c.html", "title": "Kansas lawmakers approve a plan to lure the Chiefs from Missouri by helping to finance a new stadium", "body": "ASSOCIATED PRESS\n\nTOPEKA, Kan. -- Kansas legislators approved a plan Tuesday aimed at luring the Kansas City Chiefs away from Missouri by helping to finance a new stadium for the Super Bowl champions.\n\nThe bill passed by the Republican-controlled Legislature and sent to Democratic Gov. Laura Kelly would allow Kansas to issue bonds to cover up to 70% of the costs of a new stadium in the state for the Chiefs and another for Major League Baseball's Kansas City Royals.\n\nThe state would pay off its bonds over 30 years with revenues from sports betting, Kansas Lottery ticket sales and new sales and alcohol taxes collected from shopping and entertainment districts around the sites for the new stadiums.\n\nKelly has not said whether she will sign the bill. But her chief of staff told lawmakers Monday that she had seen nothing in the version that passed that would make her veto it.\n\nPeople are also reading... CHP: Angwin woman dies after car strikes her on driveway Suspect named in fatal Napa County hit-and-run crash Napa Valley College's new student housing: How much will it cost? Napa art supply store Color Theory to close Fired American Canyon High School coach faces more sexual abuse charges Napa High School graduates celebrate an end, and a beginning Update: Man accused of murder, assault after Lake Berryessa shooting Man charged in Lake Berryessa murder pleads not guilty The Bird joins Super Duper Burgers in Napa Death of cyclists in Napa leads to criminal and civil lawsuits, documentary Finishing touches underway for Biscuits BBQ in downtown Napa Man injured in tubing accident in Lake Berryessa Regional Italian pizzas coming to Napa Valley Update: Sonoma wineries follow Point Fire's progress; air quality alerts to end Tuesday Police: Woman arrested in Napa on DUI, child endangerment allegations\n\nKansas legislators see the two teams as in play because in April, voters on the Missouri side of the Kansas City metropolitan area refused to extend a sales tax used to keep up the teams' existing stadiums, which sit side by side.\n\nThe votes came after a debate that many lawmakers said they needed to see before considering a plan to help the Super Bowl champions finance a new stadium. The measure would allow the state to issue bonds to help the Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Kansas City Royals finance new stadiums on the Kansas side of their metropolitan area, which is split by the border with Missouri.\n\nTop Republicans in the GOP-controlled Legislature had promised that the stadium proposal wouldn't be debated until the Legislature approved a plan that would cut income and property taxes by a total of $1.23 billion over the next three years. Many lawmakers argued that voters would be angry if the state helped finance new stadiums without cutting taxes.\n\n\"We definitely need to demonstrate that we're getting relief to our citizens,\" said Senate President Ty Masterson, a Wichita-area Republican who backed the stadium-financing plan.\n\nKelly called the special session to have lawmakers consider reducing taxes after she vetoed three tax-cutting plans before legislators adjourned their regular annual session May 1. The plan lawmakers approved was a compromise between her and Republican leaders.\n\n'Sunday Ticket'\n\nThe federal judge presiding over the class-action lawsuit filed by \"Sunday Ticket\" subscribers against the NFL voiced frustrations with the way the plaintiffs' attorneys have handled their side of the case.\n\nBefore Dallas Cowboys owner Jerry Jones took the stand Tuesday for a second day of testimony, U.S. District Judge Philip Gutierrez said the premise of the case was simple and that it had gone in direction that it shouldn't.\n\nThe class-action covers 2.4 million residential subscribers and 48,000 businesses who paid for the package from the 2011 through 2022 seasons.\n\nThe lawsuit claims the league broke antitrust laws by selling its package of Sunday games aired on CBS and Fox at an inflated price.\n\nBRIEFLY\n\nBEARS: Chicago signed veteran receiver and return specialist DeAndre Carter to a one-year contract. The 31-year-old Carter has 108 receptions for 1,259 yards and six touchdowns over six seasons with Philadelphia, Houston, Chicago, Washington, the Los Angeles Chargers and Las Vegas Raiders. He has averaged 9.8 yards on punt returns, and 22.4 yards with one touchdown on kickoff returns.\n\nLIONS: Detroit signed all-United Football League kicker Jake Bates, who made three field goals from at least 60 yards for the Michigan Panthers this past season. The Lions added depth at a position with veteran Michael Badgley. Undrafted rookie James Turner was released. Turner kicked for Michigan's national championship team last season after transferring from Louisville.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9660256", "eventUri": "eng-9660256", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-05-01", "textStart": 3151, "textEnd": {"uri": "8184449991", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "00:40:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T00:40:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T00:39:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://eu.cjonline.com/story/news/politics/state/2024/06/18/kansas-legislators-approve-economic-incentives-for-kansas-city-chiefs/74135146007/", "title": "Kansas lawmakers pass targeted economic incentives to fund a Chiefs or Royals stadium", "body": "Legislators in Kansas have passed a bill that would finance billions of dollars worth of construction costs for a professional sports stadium for either the Chiefs or the Royals, and the governor is expected to sign it.\n\nGov. Laura Kelly's chief of staff Will Lawrence told lawmakers that Kelly would sign the bill if it wasn't meaningfully changed from what was presented at a committee meeting on Monday. The House and Senate passed the bill without amendments, meaning an incentive package is likely to be offered to the Kansas City sports teams.\n\n\"Our members saw a vision and a future for Kansas that literally will bring hundreds of thousands if not millions of people to see the Chiefs,\" said House Speaker Dan Hawkins, R-Wichita.\n\nJackson County, Missouri, voters rejected a proposed renewal of a three-eights cent sales tax in April. Kansas lawmakers sprang into action to workshop a bill that would target the franchises. The original proposal failed earlier this session after it didn't get a vote as legislators focused on passing tax cuts, but lawmakers returned Tuesday for a special session. After tax cuts passed Tuesday, they turned their attention to the Chiefs.\n\nBefore the floor debate, a joint committee heard testimony from both sides of the debate. Legal representatives for the Chiefs and Royals, as well as lobbyists from Scoop and Score, a 501c4 dedicated to moving the Chiefs to Kansas, spoke in favor of the proposition.\n\nOpposed were some of the most influential conservative groups in the state, Americans for Prosperity Kansas and the Kansas Policy Institute.\n\nThe proposal allots 70% of funding for stadium projects with a revamped version of Sales Tax and Revenue (STAR) bonds, which would use sales taxes from the stadiums and in the surrounding business districts to pay off the bonds. It only uses state sales taxes unless a municipality gets involved and foregoes some local sales taxes for the project.\n\nThe Kansas Department of Commerce would have to approve the project after an independent economists assesses the financial impact. The state's Legislative Coordinating Council would ultimately approve any deal, which would have to be made within a year. If negotiations aren't done within a year, the Legislature can extend talks another year.\n\nThe bill also allows funds earmarked for attracting a sports franchise that are currently funded by revenues from sports gambling and from lottery revenues in excess of $71.5 million per year. The bonds would need to be paid out over a 30-year period.\n\nRep. Sean Tarwater, R-Stilwell, served as the carrier of the bill, and was tasked with describing it's provisions and answering questions from other lawmakers. He said this is an opportunity to save the sports teams from a potential move out of state, and to take it out of the hands of Missouri -- which lost the St. Louis Rams, Kansas City Kings and other professional sports teams.\n\nTarwater also pointed to STAR Bond's success in large-scale sports projects, as well as the revenue generated by the Chiefs and the civic pride in retaining the teams.\n\n\"The number one tourism project that we paid for with STAR Bonds is that racetrack up in Wyandotte County, and the number two is the stadium up there, and number three is all up in the same area. Well that area was a field when it first started,\" Tarwater said. \"We produce over $100 million in just sales tax, there are 100 new companies that were created that are now up there. There are 5,700 every-day jobs. There are houses and apartment complexes and all kinds of construction and it started with a STAR Bond.\"\n\nSeveral Democratic supporters couched criticisms of the process while still maintaining support for the bill.\n\nHouse Minority Leader Vic Miller, D-Topeka, who ultimately voted for the bill, said he didn't like the lack of transparency in the bill. He proposed an amendment that would make the deal public before approval. Under the bill, the deal will only become public after it is approved by the Legislative Coordinating Council. Tarwater said that'd allow others to undermine Kansas's deal, and the amendment failed.\n\nRep. Boog Highberger, D-Lawrence, also noted that the lead lobbyists advocating for the move Scoop and Score don't disclose their donors. He likened it to the 2022 legalization of sports gambling that had a last-minute change that diverted 80% of revenues from sports gambling to a fund to attract a professional sports team, the same fund that'll partially finance bonds in this bill.\n\nRep. Jason Probst, D-Hutchinson, stood in support of the bill but protested how efficient the legislative process is when there are money and donors involved.\n\n\"It is amazing to me the speed with which we can solve problems when they're oriented around wealth, when they're oriented around business. We can come up with a solution and we can buy every lobbyist in the building and we can create a virtual armada of lobbying effort to get this done,\" Probst said. \"But I never see anything that even comes close to this kind of effort, to this kind of solidarity on anything that actually affects the human condition -- when we have discussions about homelessness or hunger or childhood poverty.\"\n\nFiscal conservatives also raised issue with the project, noting a historical precedent of poor returns on public investments in stadiums.\n\n\"You take the serious business press and they're all over what a scandal public subsidies to stadiums actually are, that as far as a notion that it has a good return on investment, that it meets a good economic development criteria is basically laughable,\" said Rep. Paul Waggoner, R-Hutchinson.\n\nThe bill passed with 84 votes, a two-thirds majority. Overall, the votes for and against didn't have a strong partisan bias, with both parties having a similar percent of their caucus voting for either side.\n\nAfter the House debate, the Senate passed the bill after about two hours of debate. Fewer opponents raised concern in the Senate, but Sen. Molly Baumgardner, R-Louisburg, did have several pointed questions for the bill's carrier Sen. J.R. Claeys, R-Salina, on potential use of eminent domain, potential renovation costs interrupting the bond schedule and the lack of time to review the bill.\n\nSeveral dissenters also spoke out after the vote: Sen. Mike Thompson, R-Shawnee, saying the loose framework and lack of legislative oversight could be an issue, Sen. Alicia Straub, R-Ellinwood, called it a gamble and Sen. Marci Francisco, D-Lawrence, was concerned about the transfer of lottery funds in excess of $71.5 million could lose value over time.\n\nThe vote was 27-8, with most of the dissenters being Republicans.\n\nKelly commended the legislature after the House and Senate approved the bill. Kelly can't officially sign it into law until after the legislation is formally delivered to her, which could take several days.\n\n\"The bipartisan effort to invite the Chiefs and Royals to Kansas shows we're all-in on keeping our beloved teams in the Kansas City metro,\" Kelly said in a statement. \"Kansas now has the opportunity to become a professional sports powerhouse with the Chiefs and Royals potentially joining Sporting KC as major league attractions, all with robust, revenue-generating entertainment districts surrounding them providing new jobs, new visitors, and new revenues that boost the Kansas economy.\"\n\nNow the sports teams and the Kansas Department of Commerce can commence negotiating on a potential stadium. Korb Maxwell, a lawyer representing the Chiefs, said the Chiefs position remains that they're going to review all options available before making a decision, but was pleased with the decision Kansas lawmakers made in creating a path for the team to negotiate.", "source": {"uri": "eu.cjonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Tribune"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-393894445", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "19:46:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T19:46:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T19:12:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/kansas-lawmakers-pass-tax-cuts-have-eyes-on-chiefs/article_b20d9736-f847-5045-abb0-89f2a58f8658.html", "title": "Kansas lawmakers pass tax cuts, have eyes on Chiefs", "body": "ASSOCIATED PRESS\n\nTOPEKA, Kan. -- Kansas legislators cleared the way Tuesday for a debate on trying to lure the Kansas City Chiefs from Missouri by approving broad tax cuts that many lawmakers said they needed to see before considering a plan to help the Super Bowl champions finance a new stadium.\n\nThe Legislature took up the stadium proposal during a special session that convened Tuesday amid heavy lobbying for the plan. The measure would allow the state to issue bonds to help the Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Kansas City Royals finance new stadiums on the Kansas side of their metropolitan area, which is split by the border with Missouri.\n\nBut top Republicans in the GOP-controlled Legislature promised that the stadium proposal wouldn't be debated until the Legislature approved a plan that would cut income and property taxes by a total of $1.23 billion over the next three years. Many lawmakers argued that voters would be angry if the state helped finance new stadiums without cutting taxes.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nOwner of Starbeck's Smokehouse opening burger restaurant in Cedar Falls in July Deere & Co. to pay $1.1 million in back wages, interest to Black and Hispanic applicants College Football: Cedar Falls native, grandson of former Panther basketball assistant coach commits to UNI Car trapped under semitruck in collision on North Elk Run Road Two transported to hospital Saturday after motorcycle crashed in ditch Greene man airlifted after motorcycle crashes with pickup west of Plainfield One arrested in overnight Waterloo shooting that sent man to hospital MLB Baseball: Chicago Cubs sign Cedar Falls native, former Iowa Hawkeye to minor league deal Cancer journey strengthens deep bond between Relay for Life honorary survivor, caregiver Nebraska man arrested in Quasqueton cemetery crash Several injured in Bremer County crash High School Baseball: Cedar Falls' Coonradt making most of opportunities before freshman season at Iowa Waterloo offices closed for Wednesday for Juneteenth; construction at yard waste site High School Baseball: West beats East as Gardner blasts grand slam, drives in five High court ruling shields city in 'criminal' diving board suit\n\n\"We definitely need to demonstrate that we're getting relief to our citizens,\" said Senate President Ty Masterson, a Wichita-area Republican who backed the stadium-financing plan.\n\nDemocratic Gov. Laura Kelly called the special session to have lawmakers consider reducing taxes after she vetoed three tax-cutting plans before legislators adjourned their regular annual session May 1. The plan lawmakers approved was a compromise between her and Republican leaders.\n\nLegislators made no changes in the plan before passing it, 34-4 in the Senate and 121-2 in the House. Kelly pledged to sign the measure into law.\n\nOnce legislators convened the special session, Kelly couldn't control what they considered, and that created an opening to consider the stadium-financing plan. That measure would use revenues from sports betting, the state lottery and new taxes raised from the area around each new stadium to pay off the state's bonds over 30 years.\n\nThe first version of the stadium-financing plan emerged in late April, but lawmakers didn't vote on it before adjourning. It would have allowed state bonds to finance all stadium construction costs, but the version to be considered by lawmakers Tuesday would cap the amount at 70% and require legislative leaders and the governor to sign off on any bonding plan.\n\nHouse Commerce Committee Chair Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican, said the Chiefs are likely to spend between $500 million and $700 million in private funds on a new stadium.\n\nBRIEFLY\n\nLIONS: Detroit signed all-United Football League kicker Jake Bates, who made three field goals from at least 60 yards for the Michigan Panthers this past season. Detroit added depth at a position with veteran Michael Badgley.\n\nBEARS: Chicago signed veteran receiver and return specialist DeAndre Carter to a one-year contract. The 31-year-old Carter has 108 receptions for 1,259 yards and six touchdowns over six seasons with Philadelphia, Houston, Chicago, Washington, the Los Angeles Chargers and Las Vegas Mike Parson signed a truce to stop pulling existing businesses across the border. {"uri": "8183383881", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "10:21:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T10:21:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T10:18:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/kansas-lawmakers-to-debate-if-wooing-chiefs-worth-the-cost/article_49fbba81-fde0-59fc-a69b-b7aecf2e81e1.html", "title": "Kansas lawmakers to debate if wooing Chiefs worth the cost", "body": "ASSOCIATED PRESS\n\nTOPEKA, Kan. -- Kansas legislators trying to lure the Kansas City Chiefs to their state argue that helping the Super Bowl champions build a new stadium could bring Kansas millions of dollars in income taxes from players and coaches, which are currently going to Missouri.\n\nSome economists are dubious that new revenues from \"jock taxes\" would be significant for Kansas, and a debate over the question emerged ahead of a special session of the Kansas Legislature set to convene Tuesday. Lawmakers expect to consider a plan to authorize state bonds to help the Chiefs and professional baseball's Kansas City Royals finance new stadiums on the Kansas side of their metropolitan area, which is split by the border with Missouri.\n\nProfessional athletes and touring entertainers pay income taxes not only in their home states but also other states where they perform, if those states impose income taxes. For athletes, Kansas taxes a percentage of their income based on how many games they play in the state -- so that if a visiting minor-league infielder has 12 of his team's 120 games each season in Wichita, 10% of their income is taxed.\n\nPeople are also reading... CHP: Angwin woman dies after car strikes her on driveway Suspect named in fatal Napa County hit-and-run crash Napa Valley College's new student housing: How much will it cost? Napa art supply store Color Theory to close Fired American Canyon High School coach faces more sexual abuse charges Napa High School graduates celebrate an end, and a beginning Update: Man accused of murder, assault after Lake Berryessa shooting Death of cyclists in Napa leads to criminal and civil lawsuits, documentary Finishing touches underway for Biscuits BBQ in downtown Napa Man charged in Lake Berryessa murder pleads not guilty Update: Sonoma wineries follow Point Fire's progress; air quality alerts to end Tuesday The Bird joins Super Duper Burgers in Napa Police: Woman arrested in Napa on DUI, child endangerment allegations Vintage High School graduates took the journey of their lives Man sentenced in Napa drunk driving murder case\n\nEconomists who've studied pro sports teams for decades have concluded that subsidizing their stadiums isn't worth the cost for their communities. But supporters of bringing the Chiefs and Royals to Kansas believe that skepticism doesn't properly consider taxes from the large incomes of the best professional players.\n\n\"The amount of dollars that come in from the income tax side offset a good portion of some of the things that we're doing here,\" said Kansas state Sen. J.R. Claeys, a Republican from central Kansas who is working on the stadium plan.\n\nKansas already collects some income taxes from professional athletes, though the state Department of Revenue does not have figures. The state is home to NASCAR's Kansas Speedway, professional soccer's Sporting KC and several minor league baseball and hockey teams.\n\nMissouri is home for the Chiefs, the Royals, Major League Baseball's St. Louis Cardinals and the National Hockey League's St. Louis Blues, plus two minor-league baseball teams.\n\nMissouri has collected nearly $34 million in income taxes from professional athletes during the current budget year that began July 1, up 9% from the $31 million collected the previous year, according to the state. However, during the current budget year, when the Chiefs won their third Super Bowl in five years, taxes from football players jumped 39% from about $14 million to $19 million.\n\n'Sunday ticket'\n\nNFL Commissioner Roger Goodell reiterated during testimony in federal court Monday that the league's \"Sunday Ticket\" package, the subject of a class-action lawsuit, is a premium product while also defending the league's broadcast model.\n\nGoodell was called as a witness by the NFL as the trial for the lawsuit filed by \"Sunday Ticket\" subscribers entered its third week.\n\nThe class-action covers 2.4 million residential subscribers and 48,000 businesses who paid for the package from 2011 through 2022. The lawsuit claims the league broke antitrust laws by selling its package of out-of-market Sunday afternoon games at an inflated price.\n\nThe subscribers also say the league restricted competition by offering \"Sunday Ticket\" only on a satellite provider.\n\n'Hard Knocks'\n\nThe division best known for heated rivalries and star quarterbacks will be featured on HBO's \"Hard Knocks\" series this upcoming season. It's the first time the Emmy Award-winning series has chronicled an entire division.\n\nLast season, the AFC North's four teams -- the Baltimore Ravens, Cincinnati Bengals, Cleveland Browns and Pittsburgh Steelers -- all finished with winning records.\n\n\"Hard Knocks: In Season with the AFC North\" will debut on Dec. 3 and run through the rest of the regular season and playoffs.\n\nThe popular series will feature the Chicago Bears' training camp this summer.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on {"uri": "8184187151", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "19:38:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T19:38:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T19:38:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/kansas-lawmakers-pass-tax-cuts-have-eyes-on-chiefs/article_adada3f9-1386-59c8-baaa-5bde000b93a6.html", "title": "Kansas lawmakers pass tax cuts, have eyes on Chiefs", "body": "TOPEKA, Kan. -- Kansas legislators cleared the way Tuesday for a debate on trying to lure the Kansas City Chiefs from Missouri by approving broad tax cuts that many lawmakers said they needed to see before considering a plan to help the Super Bowl champions finance a new stadium.\n\nThe Legislature took up the stadium proposal during a special session that convened Tuesday amid heavy lobbying for the plan. The measure would allow the state to issue bonds to help the Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Kansas City Royals finance new stadiums on the Kansas side of their metropolitan area, which is split by the border with Missouri.\n\nBut top Republicans in the GOP-controlled Legislature promised that the stadium proposal wouldn't be debated until the Legislature approved a plan that would cut income and property taxes by a total of $1.23 billion over the next three years. Many lawmakers argued that voters would be angry if the state helped finance new stadiums without cutting taxes.\n\nPeople are also reading... Marion woman charged with sexual exploitation of a child McDowell schools recognizes student for science competition success; staff for dedication McDowell sheriff's office looking for suspect, car in armed robbery case Don't throw out that mail: many NC families set to receive 'SUN Bucks' to help feed children this summer Update: Runaway teen located McDowell resident asks county to consider school safety; leaders to approve budget this month Man arrested for stealing vehicle, wallet of man who died in Old Fort McDowell County Schools Alumni Spotlight: Josie Morgan found career in health care McDowell alum Zach Franklin having a solid first half for Winston-Salem Dash Emergency personnel searching for missing man in Marion Update: Emergency personnel locate missing disabled man Juneteenth Freedom Festival kicks off Saturday Developer seeking federal money for $50 million Clinchfield mill housing project Mission Health Center McDowell welcomes new pediatric surgeon Old Fort could see higher property tax, water, sewer rates; public can weigh in on Monday\n\n\"We definitely need to demonstrate that we're getting relief to our citizens,\" said Senate President Ty Masterson, a Wichita-area Republican who backed the stadium-financing plan.\n\nDemocratic Gov. Laura Kelly called the special session to have lawmakers consider reducing taxes after she vetoed three tax-cutting plans before legislators adjourned their regular annual session May 1. The plan lawmakers approved was a compromise between her and Republican leaders.\n\nLegislators made no changes in the plan before passing it, 34-4 in the Senate and 121-2 in the House. Kelly pledged to sign the measure into law.\n\nOnce legislators convened the special session, Kelly couldn't control what they considered, and that created an opening to consider the stadium-financing plan. That measure would use revenues from sports betting, the state lottery and new taxes raised from the area around each new stadium to pay off the state's bonds over 30 years.\n\nThe first version of the stadium-financing plan emerged in late April, but lawmakers didn't vote on it before adjourning. It would have allowed state bonds to finance all stadium construction costs, but the version to be considered by lawmakers Tuesday would cap the amount at 70% and require legislative leaders and the governor to sign off on any bonding plan.\n\nHouse Commerce Committee Chair Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican, said the Chiefs are likely to spend between $500 million and $700 million in private funds on a new stadium.\n\nBRIEFLY\n\nLIONS: Detroit signed all-United Football League kicker Jake Bates, who made three field goals from at least 60 yards for the Michigan Panthers this past season. "eng-9660256", "eventUri": "eng-9660256", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Topeka, Kansas"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, "extractedDates": {"uri": "8184020800", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "17:15:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T17:15:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T17:14:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "http://thebeaconnews.org/stories/2024/06/18/kansas-star-bonds-chiefs-royals/", "title": "Kansas hoping to use STAR bonds to lure Chiefs or Royals", "body": "Kansas lawmakers see this as a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity.\n\nKansas could finance up to 70% of a Chiefs or Royals stadium under a new proposal to lure professional sports teams to the state.\n\nKansas lawmakers have returned to Topeka for a special tax-cutting session and are expected to vote on a STAR bond proposal to finance a new stadium.\n\nSTAR bonds, or sales tax and revenue bonds, pay for tourist attractions and then use the sales taxes collected at those attractions to pay off the construction debt. For stadiums, that means sales taxes on food, tickets or merchandise in that area are used to pay off the bulk of the debt instead of taxpayer dollars in the state general fund.\n\nThat also means that sales tax dollars that might have otherwise paid for public services -- including entertainment spending that shifts from an existing business to whatever a STAR bond financed -- go to the project that's financed with state help. Cities can opt out of offering their sales tax under the proposed bill.\n\nA Chiefs or Royals relocation from Missouri is marketed as a once-in-a-lifetime chance. Rep. Sean Tarwater, a Stilwell Republican, said the new stadiums and surrounding entertainment districts would pay for themselves.\n\n\"(Kansans are) not going to pay a dime unless they visit the district,\" Tarwater said.\n\nBut Kansas has a mixed record on STAR bond projects, and the state has never used them to subsidize an NFL or MLB team before.\n\nA 2021 audit of the state's STAR bond system found that some projects may need over 100 years to pay off their debt. But the Kansas Department of Commerce said almost 80% of STAR bonds projects are expected to pay off early -- often in a few decades.\n\nThe audit and a 2019 Kansas CIty Star article paint a bleak picture of STAR bonds, though, saying they are risky and used too often.\n\nThe Prairiefire development in Overland Park -- which has a museum, restaurants and shopping -- defaulted on its bond just months ago. Heartland Motorsports Park in Topeka closed down and is up for auction. The Schlitterbahn Water Park never recovered from the death of a then-legislator's son on a waterslide and is another closed-down STAR bond project.\n\n\"When everybody is talking about pie-in-the-sky dreams and all the different possibilities, you have to have an economist say, 'Here's what actually happens. Here are the facts.' ... STAR bonds ... simply do not work,\" economist Michael Austin told lawmakers.\n\nThe Kansas Speedway, opened in 2001, was the state's first STAR bonds project. The original bond was for $24.3 million and has $10.6 million in outstanding debt, a 2023 report from the Department of Commerce said.\n\nKansas has successfully funded some stadium projects through STAR bonds.\n\nChildren's Mercy Park, opened in 2011 and home of Sporting KC, was originally issued $150 million in bonds and paid off its debt early.\n\nIn 2023, the Royals sold 1.3 million tickets and the Chiefs sold another 638,000. The Royals were a last-place team that year and poor play scared off some fans. The team sold 2.7 million regular-season tickets during its 2015 World Series run.\n\nA STAR bond district bringing in 2.7 million visitors is comparable to the Wichita River District, which had around 3 million visitors in 2018 and 2019.\n\nThe river district is paying back a $55.3 million bond, while a Chiefs or Royals district could cost substantially more.\n\nThe cost of any stadium is purely speculative, but the new Las Vegas Raiders stadium cost $1.9 billion when it opened in 2020. The new Texas Rangers stadium was $1.2 billion when it opened in 2020. That could mean around $1 billion or more for just a new Chiefs or Royals stadium.\n\nWhen the Royals asked Jackson County, Missouri, taxpayers to extend a sales tax to pay for a new downtown stadium earlier this year, that would have eaten up about $2 billion over 40 years to pay the principal and interest on construction costs. Half of that sales tax money would have gone to the Chiefs.\n\nTarwater, the Stilwell Republican, said he expects the stadium districts to draw far more than the river district. For starters, the stadiums could host concerts, college football playoff games or even March Madness Final Four visits.\n\nTarwater said the Arizona Diamondbacks draw millions more people who aren't at the game because of a district around the stadium.\n\n\"You're talking 70-80,000 people coming to a region several times a year,\" he said. \"That generates a lot of commerce.\"\n\nSome STAR bonds districts also went under because the attraction closed. It's been decades since a major American sports team went out of business.\n\nThe Legislature is expected to vote on a STAR bonds proposal on Tuesday. But the Legislature doesn't have the final say on how much is spent. That falls to the secretary for the Department of Commerce.\n\nBob North, chief counsel for the Department of Commerce, said STAR bonds usually only fund 30% of the proposed projects. The department could authorize financing for 50% of the bonds, but it determines how much bond funding to use by looking at expected revenue.\n\nKansas is one of few states using STAR bonds to fund projects. North said that gives the state an edge in economic development.\n\nNot only does it create new tourist attractions, he said, but it improves the economic well-being of the state.\n\n\"We believe STAR bonds work,\" he said. \"Over time, that's going to continue to be proven to be true.\"", "source": {"uri": "thebeaconnews.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beacon: Kansas"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8184180237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "19:32:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T19:32:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T19:31:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/kansas-lawmakers-pass-tax-cuts-have-eyes-on-chiefs/article_f78176b7-3e1a-51c9-ac06-9899061c2472.html", "title": "Kansas lawmakers pass tax cuts, have eyes on Chiefs", "body": "ASSOCIATED PRESS\n\nTOPEKA, Kan. -- Kansas legislators cleared the way Tuesday for a debate on trying to lure the Kansas City Chiefs from Missouri by approving broad tax cuts that many lawmakers said they needed to see before considering a plan to help the Super Bowl champions finance a new stadium.\n\nThe Legislature took up the stadium proposal during a special session that convened Tuesday amid heavy lobbying for the plan. The measure would allow the state to issue bonds to help the Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Kansas City Royals finance new stadiums on the Kansas side of their metropolitan area, which is split by the border with Missouri.\n\nBut top Republicans in the GOP-controlled Legislature promised that the stadium proposal wouldn't be debated until the Legislature approved a plan that would cut income and property taxes by a total of $1.23 billion over the next three years. Many lawmakers argued that voters would be angry if the state helped finance new stadiums without cutting taxes.\n\nPeople are also reading... PBS Appalachia studio to open late fall inside Hard Rock Corner Dog House keeps the tradition going EMORY & HENRY ATHLETICS: Sensabaugh has personal investment in new role as E&H AD Isaiah 117 House breaks ground for new home in Bristol, Va. PREP FOOTBALL NOTES: Virginia High vs. John Marshall to occur on gridiron; Richlands has new O.C. in Bubba Edwards; Honaker coach faces legal issues Local Briefs: Laisure transfers to Science Hill; Honaker's Lowe earns all-state soccer honors Man arrested after driving vehicle with deceased female in rear seat Board approves exception for Taylors Valley cafe TBI investigating fatal officer-involved shooting Blueberries abound at the Berry Patch Farm Local Briefs: Eastside's Clay earns Class 1 softball player of the year award Burger Bar moves customers to a different era Bristol Casino reports second highest revenue month since opening Charges filed following pursuit, head-on collision in Wise County Chesterfield County schools employee charged with possessing child porn\n\n\"We definitely need to demonstrate that we're getting relief to our citizens,\" said Senate President Ty Masterson, a Wichita-area Republican who backed the stadium-financing plan.\n\nDemocratic Gov. Laura Kelly called the special session to have lawmakers consider reducing taxes after she vetoed three tax-cutting plans before legislators adjourned their regular annual session May 1. The plan lawmakers approved was a compromise between her and Republican leaders.\n\nLegislators made no changes in the plan before passing it, 34-4 in the Senate and 121-2 in the House. Kelly pledged to sign the measure into law.\n\nOnce legislators convened the special session, Kelly couldn't control what they considered, and that created an opening to consider the stadium-financing plan. That measure would use revenues from sports betting, the state lottery and new taxes raised from the area around each new stadium to pay off the state's bonds over 30 years.\n\nThe first version of the stadium-financing plan emerged in late April, but lawmakers didn't vote on it before adjourning. It would have allowed state bonds to finance all stadium construction costs, but the version to be considered by lawmakers Tuesday would cap the amount at 70% and require legislative leaders and the governor to sign off on any bonding plan.\n\nHouse Commerce Committee Chair Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican, said the Chiefs are likely to spend between $500 million and $700 million in private funds on a new stadium.\n\nBRIEFLY\n\nLIONS: Detroit signed all-United Football League kicker Jake Bates, who made three field goals from at least 60 yards for the Michigan Panthers this past season. Detroit added depth at a position with veteran Michael Badgley.\n\nBEARS: Chicago signed veteran receiver and return specialist DeAndre Carter to a one-year contract. The 31-year-old Carter has 108 receptions for 1,259 yards and six touchdowns over six seasons with Philadelphia, Houston, Chicago, Washington, the Los Angeles Chargers and Las Vegas Raiders.\n\nBe the {"uri": "8185541574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "15:10:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T15:10:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T15:09:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.fieldofschemes.com/2024/06/19/21586/kansas-approves-blank-check-bill-for-royals-and-chiefs-stadiums-leaves-final-spending-decision-up-to-handful-of-politicians/", "title": "Kansas approves \"blank check\" bill for Royals and Chiefs stadiums, leaves final spending decision up to handful of politicians", "body": "Yesterday, after only a few hours of discussion and zero public hearings, the Kansas state house voted 84-38 to approve a bill to pay for up to 70% of the cost of new stadiums for the Royals and Chiefs; the state senate voted 27-8 to approve the measure shortly afterward.\n\nAs discussed yesterday, the bill authorizes the sale of bonds starting at $700 million for each stadium project, and with no upward limit, to be repaid with a combination of sales tax kickbacks and state lottery money. Additional details include:\n\nBoth Chiefs owner Clark Hunt and Royals owner John Sherman were noncommittal after the vote about taking Kansas up on its stadium offers, and it seems very likely that this will be just the beginning of a cross-border bidding war. (Missouri House Majority Leader Jonathan Patterson said any counteroffer will likely wait until after the August primaries, because \"before the primary, there would be a lot of politics involved,\" which is a polite way of saying \"we don't want people holding us responsible for our stadium vote on election day.\") This would be in apparent violation of a truce agreed to in 2019 by Kelly and Missouri Gov. Mike Parson to stop poaching each other's businesses with tax breaks -- that agreement is supposed to be legally binding, though it also expires next year, so Kansas may just have to wait a few months to make an actual offer to the team owners.\n\nTl;dr: Kansas elected officials just dropped a $2.45-billion-and-up subsidy package on the table to lure the Chiefs and Royals across the border, with no public debate, despite it being against the law. There's a lot to be said here, but suffice to say that predictions the national tide was turning against giant stadium subsidies following the defeat of the Royals/Chiefs sales tax referendum and the {"uri": "8187373518", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:20:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:20:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:18:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.sportsbusinessjournal.com/Articles/2024/06/20/missouri-response-kansas-bill", "title": "Missouri unlikely to respond to Kansas plan to lure Chiefs, Royals before August", "body": "Missouri lawmakers are \"not likely to pass a counteroffer\" to Kansas' passage of \"an ambitious plan to lure the Chiefs and Royals\" across the border \"until after the August elections,\" according to Kacen Bayless of the K.C. STAR. Missouri House Majority Leader Jonathan Patterson said that it was \"very unlikely\" for lawmakers to \"respond to the Kansas proposal in a special session before the primaries.\" The plan could \"turn a Civil War-era border war into a financial bidding war between the two states.\" The Missouri General Assembly ended its annual legislative session last month and lawmakers \"won't meet again to pass legislation until January\" unless Gov. Mike Parson \"calls a special session.\" Parson, an \"ardent Chiefs fan,\" has \"previously vowed to fight to keep the teams in Missouri.\" Patterson acknowledged that Missouri \"does not have the authority to issue STAR bonds like Kansas.\" But he was clear that \"we aren't going to do nothing.\" Patterson: \"We'll just have to gather and get together and see what we can do.\" He added, \"We'll get together and come up with a plan to keep the Chiefs and Royals in Missouri.\" Any Missouri proposal that uses state funds to keep either team is \"almost certain to run into resistance from a group of hard-right senators in the state Senate\" (K.C. STAR, 6/18).\n\nLINES ARE DRAWN: In K.C., Sam McDowell writes we are \"on the verge of a distinct line in the sand now.\" K.C. Mayor Quinton Lucas said that it is a \"'regrettable' violation of a border war truce.\" According to sources, the Chiefs are \"privately telling those involved a move to Kansas will get real consideration.\" With its latest bill, Kansas has \"provided an avenue for an extremely, even overly, team-friendly financial option that its Missouri counterparts have expressed not only a reluctance to match but outright doubt.\" It is quite evident that the Royals and Chiefs have \"leverage.\" The Missouri response is \"biggest mystery in the aftermath,\" because key members of its state legislature there have \"been vocal in opposition to using tax dollars on two stadiums.\" The reason for the existence of the so-called border war truce -- to prevent businesses from using an offer from one state to improve an offer from their neighbors, increasing the public cost while the benefit to the region as a whole \"remains the same.\" It is \"in place because people tend to respond,\" McDowell wrote in other words, and he would be \"stunned if Missouri didn't have some sort of response.\" Developer Robb Heineman and sports stadium architecture company MANICA are \"offering a vision for a Royals stadium in Kansas City's West Bottoms, ... particular distinction.\" The stadium and its surrounding development \"would sit in both states.\" McDowell noted that Heineman has \"yet to bring this blueprint to the Royals, nor has he sought the support of politicos key to its viability\" (K.C. {"uri": "8184390291", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:20:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:20:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:19:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://www.democraticunderground.com/100219044069", "title": "Kansas House passes incentive bill to lure Kansas City Chiefs, Royals", "body": "TOPEKA -- The Kansas City Royals or Chiefs could receive hundreds of millions of dollars in sales tax revenue to move from Missouri and build new stadiums in Kansas under legislation passed Tuesday by the House.\n\nAfter an hour of debate, the House voted 84-38 to approve legislation that would expand a state incentive program in an attempt to lure one or both teams from Kansas City.\n\nIt now heads to the Kansas Senate, which is expected to take up the bill Tuesday afternoon.\n\nState Rep. Sean Tarwater, a Republican from Stilwell, said Missouri had a history of losing professional sports teams and implored fellow House members to pass the legislation.\n\n\"I ask you today, do you really want to put that type of an economic generation in the hands of the state of Missouri?\" Tarwater said just before the vote.\n\nhttps://kansasreflector.com/2024/06/18/kansas-house-passes-incentive-bill-to-lure-kansas-city-chiefs-royals/", "source": {"uri": "democraticunderground.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Democratic Underground"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City_Chiefs", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kansas City Chiefs"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City_Royals", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kansas City Royals"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Missouri", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Missouri"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Missouri"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topeka,_Kansas", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Topeka, Kansas"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Topeka, Kansas"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kansas"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Kansas"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sean_Tarwater", "type": "person", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Sean Tarwater"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_Senate", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Kansas Senate"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)", "type": "org", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Republican Party (United States)"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kansas_City,_Missouri", "type": "loc", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Kansas City, Missouri"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Kansas City, Missouri"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stilwell,_Kansas", "type": "loc", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Stilwell, Kansas"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Stilwell, Kansas"}, "country": {"uri": "8184413840", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:52:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:52:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:51:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://finance.yahoo.com/news/kansas-lawmakers-pass-targeted-economic-233102132.html", "title": "Kansas lawmakers pass targeted economic incentives to fund a Chiefs or Royals stadium", "body": "Legislators in Kansas have passed a bill that would finance billions of dollars worth of construction costs for a professional sports stadium for either the Chiefs or the Royals, and the governor is expected to sign it.\n\nGov. Laura Kelly's chief of staff Will Lawrence told lawmakers that Kelly would sign the bill if it wasn't meaningfully changed from what was presented at a committee meeting on Monday. The House and Senate passed the bill without amendments, meaning an incentive package likely to be offered to the Kansas City sports teams.\n\nJackson County, Missouri, voters rejected a proposed renewal of a three-eights cent sales tax in April. Kansas lawmakers sprang into action to workshop a bill that would target the franchises. The original proposal failed earlier this session after it didn't get a vote as legislators focused on passing tax cuts, but lawmakers returned Tuesday for a special session. After tax cuts passed Tuesday, they turned their attention to the Chiefs.\n\nBefore the floor debate, a joint committee heard testimony from both sides of the debate. Legal representatives for the Chiefs and Royals, as well as lobbyists from Scoop and Score, a 501c4 dedicated to moving the Chiefs to Kansas, spoke in favor of the proposition.\n\nOpposed were some of the most influential conservative groups in the state, Americans for Prosperity Kansas and the Kansas Policy Institute.\n\nThe proposal allots 70% of funding for stadium projects with a revamped version of Sales Tax and Revenue (STAR) bonds, which would use sales taxes from the stadiums and in the surrounding business districts to pay off the bonds. It only uses state sales taxes unless a municipality gets involved and foregoes some local sales taxes for the project.\n\nThe Kansas Department of Commerce would have to approve the project after an independent economists assesses the financial impact. The state's Legislative Coordinating Council would ultimately approve any deal, which would have to be made within a year. If negotiations aren't done within a year, the Legislature can extend talks another year.\n\nThe bill also allows funds earmarked for attracting a sports franchise that are currently funded by revenues from sports gambling and from lottery revenues in excess of $71.5 million per year. The bonds would need to be paid out over a 30-year period.\n\nRep. Sean Tarwater, R-Stilwell, served as the carrier of the bill, and was tasked with describing it's provisions and answering questions from other lawmakers. He said this is an opportunity to save the sports teams from a potential move out of state, and to take it out of the hands of Missouri -- which lost the St. Louis Rams, Kansas City Kings and other professional sports teams.\n\nTarwater also pointed to STAR Bond's success in large-scale sports projects, as well as the revenue generated by the Chiefs and the civic pride in retaining the teams.\n\n\"It was good for the racetrack, the stadium, the three are all in that area,\" Tarwater said. \"That was a field when it first started, and it was generating zero dollars in one of the poorest counties in the state. Look at what it's doing today, we produce over $100 million in just sales tax, there are 100 new companies that were created up there, started with a STAR Bond.\"\n\nSeveral Democratic supporters couched criticisms of the process while still maintaining support for the bill.\n\nHouse Minority Leader Vic Miller, D-Topeka, who ultimately voted for the bill, said he didn't like the lack of transparency in the bill. He proposed an amendment that would make the deal public before approval. Under the bill, the deal will only become public after it is approved by the Legislative Coordinating Council. Tarwater said that'd allow others to undermine Kansas's deal, and the amendment failed.\n\nRep. Boog Highberger, D-Lawrence, also noted that the lead lobbyists advocating for the move Scoop and Score don't disclose their donors. He likened it to the 2022 legalization of sports gambling that had a last-minute change that diverted 80% of revenues from sports gambling to a fund to attract a professional sports team, the same fund that'll partially finance bonds in this bill.\n\nRep. Jason Probst, D-Hutchinson, stood in support of the bill but protested how efficient the legislative process is when there are money and donors involved.\n\n\"It's amazing to me the speed with which we can solve problems when they're oriented around wealth, when they're oriented around business, we can come up with this solution and we can buy every lobbyist in the building and create a virtual armada of lobbying to get this done,\" Probst said. \"But haven't seen anything like this on concerns to the human condition. We do not see this collective effort for homelessness, drug addiction.\"\n\nFiscal conservatives also raised issue with the project, noting a historical precedent of poor returns on public investments in stadiums.\n\n\"You'll see study after study on what a bad return it is, what a bad investment it is, the folks who are pushing it frankly have some sort of financial benefit themselves,\" said Rep. Paul Waggoner, R-Hutchinson. \"Reality is past cities who thought this is some eco devo tool and it isn't. This isn't a conservative perspective, Brookings, Journal of Urban Affairs, lots of people looked at it and it's uniformly a negative indicator.\"\n\nThe bill passed with 84 votes, a two-thirds majority. Overall, the votes for and against didn't have a strong partisan bias, with both parties having a similar percent of their caucus voting for either side.\n\nAfter the House debate, the Senate passed the bill after about two hours of debate. Fewer opponents raised concern in the Senate, but Sen. Molly Baumgardner, R-Louisburg, did have several pointed questions for the bill's carrier Sen. J.R. Claeys, R-Salina, on potential use of eminent domain, potential renovation costs interrupting the bond schedule and the lack of time to review the bill.\n\nSeveral dissenters also spoke out after the vote: Sen. Mike Thompson, R-Shawnee, saying the loose framework and lack of legislative oversight could be an issue, Sen. Alicia Straub, R-Ellinwood, called it a gamble and Sen. Marci Francisco, D-Lawrence, was concerned about the transfer of lottery funds in excess of $71.5 million could lose value over time.\n\nThe vote was 27-8.\n\nKelly commended the legislature after the House and Senate approved the bill. Kelly can't officially sign it into law until after the legislation is formally delivered to her, which could take several days.\n\n\"The bipartisan effort to invite the Chiefs and Royals to Kansas shows we're all-in on keeping our beloved teams in the Kansas City metro,\" Kelly said in a statement. \"Kansas now has the opportunity to become a professional sports powerhouse with the Chiefs and Royals potentially joining Sporting KC as major league attractions, all with robust, revenue-generating entertainment districts surrounding them providing new jobs, new visitors, and new revenues that boost the Kansas economy.\"\n\nNow the sports teams and the Kansas Department of Commerce can commence negotiating on a potential stadium. Korb Maxwell, a lawyer representing the Chiefs, said the Chiefs position remains that they're going to review all options available before making a decision, but was pleased with the decision Kansas lawmakers made in creating a path for the team to negotiate.", "source": {"uri": "finance.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo!
