"originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9660256", "eventUri": "eng-9660256", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1137254901960785, "wgt": 138, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-394591632", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "11:04:27", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T11:04:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article289376128.html", "title": "KCK community groups may lack leverage over Chiefs, Royals under Kansas stadiums plan", "body": "Reality Check is a Star series holding those with power to account and shining a light on their decisions. Have a suggestion for a future story? Email our journalists at RealityCheck@kcstar.com.\n\nWhen the Kansas City Chiefs and Royals asked Jackson County voters to approve a stadiums sales tax earlier this year, the teams negotiated with local activists seeking clear community benefits. Both sides campaigned publicly. Royals owner John Sherman stumped for votes.\n\nIt was messy, but also democratic.\n\nThe Kansas Legislature on Tuesday passed a plan aimed at attracting the teams away from Missouri that relies on potentially billions of dollars in bonds to finance new stadiums. This time, the process will take place mostly behind closed doors - potentially even more so than in Jackson County - with key decisions made by just a handful of officials.\n\nActivists and organizations enjoyed significant leverage during the Jackson County campaign because they could mobilize voters either for or against the sales tax. It's unlikely to be the case this time, since an agreement with teams won't require a public vote or a vote of the full Legislature.\n\nThat reality has begun to settle in the minds of some activists in Wyandotte County, which has been floated as a potential new home for one or both teams. And as efforts to win the teams progress, some are concerned about their ability to effectively advocate for community benefits.\n\n\"Even though it didn't ultimately get passed on the Missouri side, that model of community partners being at the table and a community benefits agreement being an essential piece shouldn't be skipped in Kansas,\" said Marcus Winn, a community organizer in Kansas City, Kansas.\n\n\"If any teams or government agencies were to try to skip that part of the process, just because they can, that'd be a huge red flag.\"\n\nUnder the proposal, Kansas could issue Sales Tax and Revenue, or STAR, bonds to finance up to 70% of the costs of stadiums for one or both teams. The bonds would be paid back over 30 years by tax revenue from within the stadiums and surrounding development, along with sports betting and some Lottery revenues.\n\nSecret deliberation OK'd\n\nThe bill empowers the Kansas secretary of commerce, Lt. Gov. David Toland, to negotiate an agreement with the Chiefs or Royals. Cities and counties also have the option to negotiate directly with the teams, but aren't required to participate.\n\nAny proposed agreement would go before the Legislative Coordinating Council, or LCC - comprised of the eight highest-ranking lawmakers from both parties - for approval. Republicans hold a 6-2 majority on the council.\n\nThe LCC would be allowed to deliberate in secret. Only after the LCC approves an agreement would the document become public. Rejected agreements would remain confidential. In effect, the public would only learn what's in a deal between Kansas and the teams after the fact.\n\n\"Fundamentally, if we're going to ask the LCC to approve something so huge, the public ought to have some notice of what it is they're being asked,\" House Minority Leader Vic Miller, a Topeka Democrat, said.\n\nSTAR bonds need reform to allow for more public input, said Sen. Mike Thompson, a Shawnee Republican. The bill doesn't contain an ability for the Legislature or voters to sign off on a final deal.\n\n\"While I appreciate the LCC as an added check, I also believe that any deal of this magnitude should be subject of the Legislature or even the people within the county or counties in which a district would sit,\" Thompson said.\n\nSen. J.R. Claeys, a Salina Republican who helped spearhead the STAR bonds legislation, said making agreements public before LCC approval would essentially give other states and cities a playbook to copy.\n\n\"At this point you would need to, through our guardrails that we've set up here, decide that you're going to trust the Department of Commerce is going to create a deal that is agreeable by the Legislative Coordinating Council that is represented by the leadership that we have voted upon in this body,\" Claeys said on the Senate floor.\n\nDuring the lead up to the Jackson County vote, the Chiefs and Royals pledged to contribute a combined $266 million over a span of 40 years toward various social and economic causes. The final agreement was a far cry from what community groups had initially asked for from the teams.\n\nThe Chiefs said their share would be $126 million, and the Royals would give $140 million. The money would have been distributed by separate governing boards, which would have been appointed by the county and the teams. Those boards would have then decided specifically where the money would go.\n\nEyes on Wyandotte\n\nThe Kansas legislation doesn't name a location for either team. But much focus has been on Wyandotte County as a potential site thanks to the availability of land, its proximity to the current home of the Chiefs and Royals and a track record of successful economic development projects made with STAR bonds.\n\nCommercial development can be a fierce political issue in Wyandotte County, where the western end has transformed into a top state tourism destination and other communities eastward face serious economic struggles, including high poverty rates.\n\nIn late December, Unified Government commissioners adopted a new local ordinance that established a community benefits fund.\n\nThe fund relies on developer fees to pay for local projects that include affordable housing, senior home repair or child care programs. It was the product of a task force initiated by Mayor Tyrone Garner, who has pointed to local tax relief and greater economic equity as a priority of his tenure.\n\nActivists who spoke to The Star on Tuesday about the incentives forwarded by state lawmakers highlighted clear community benefits as a necessity of any deal -- should one come to pass.\n\nLora McDonald, executive director of MORE2, a Kansas City metro social justice organization, said development in Wyandotte County is an entirely different story than in Jackson County. And she pointed to the areas surrounding the current stadiums on Kansas City, Missouri's eastern border.\n\n\"I think the voters and the people of Kansas should demand and expect more from projects like these and from economic development,\" McDonald said. \"If you look at Kansas City, Missouri and the area around the stadiums, it's not a desirable area. So, what do they want that to be like at the end of the day? And how do they want to benefit from this coming to their community other than bragging rights?\"\n\n\"If we see a window, we would like to be trying to get in it,\" McDonald added. \"But I don't see one. I don't know what's gonna happen.\"\n\nLouise Lynch, of Wyandotte County's Community Conscience Action Network, questioned why the conversation around incentives had reached Topeka before a public forum locally with elected officials.\n\n\"That's a problem. Not to discuss the good, the bad and the ugly, or any of it,\" Lynch said, pointing to a process that has \"rapidly\" unfolded in the statehouse.\n\n\"We are very concerned,\" Lynch said. \"Are we going to have a seat at the table? {"uri": "2024-06-396193833", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:49:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:49:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:46:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.kmbc.com/article/royals-ballpark-west-bottoms-renderings-kansas/61191527", "title": "Architecture firm shares renderings of a Royals stadium in the West Bottoms", "body": "An architecture firm has shared its vision of a new Kansas City Royals ballpark in the West Bottoms that would allow home runs to cross the state line into Missouri. On Thursday, MANICA Architecture -- the firm behind renderings of a possible domed Chiefs stadium floated to Kansas lawmakers -- shared new mock-ups of what a new Royals stadium in Kansas might look like. MANICA has been behind the designs of multiple stadiums across the country.The KCK-based firm envisions the Royals finding a new home near the Kansas River, right next to Interstate 670 and State Line Road. The renderings were released shortly after the Kansas Legislature passed a massive STAR Bonds package that would give the Chiefs and Royals massive tax incentives if they moved from Missouri to Kansas.In a statement detailing the renderings, MANICA said that the ballpark would honor the dimensions of Kauffman Stadium, allowing future players to protect the legacy of the Royals' record books.According to MANICA, the Kansas-Missouri state line is uniquely aligned with the Right field fence, where home runs could literally be hit from one state into another.The design would also integrate Kauffman's iconic water fountains and crown-shaped scoreboard. Other features of the conceptual ballpark include a mixed-use district with bars, restaurants, beer gardens, rooftop terraces and watch parties -- all with a stadium orientation that would frame downtown Kansas City's skyline.MANICA says its design master plan would include provisions for a hotel, offices, and residential lofts. The plan also allows for an improved riverfront with recreational activities, landscaping, and a pedestrian promenade.\n\nAn architecture firm has shared its vision of a new Kansas City Royals ballpark in the West Bottoms that would allow home runs to cross the state line into Missouri.\n\nOn Thursday, MANICA Architecture -- the firm behind renderings of a possible domed Chiefs stadium floated to Kansas lawmakers -- shared new mock-ups of what a new Royals stadium in Kansas might look like.\n\nMANICA has been behind the designs of multiple stadiums across the country.\n\nThe KCK-based firm envisions the Royals finding a new home near the Kansas River, right next to Interstate 670 and State Line Road.\n\nThe renderings were released shortly after the Kansas Legislature passed a massive STAR Bonds package that would give the Chiefs and Royals massive tax incentives if they moved from Missouri to Kansas.\n\nIn a statement detailing the renderings, MANICA said that the ballpark would honor the dimensions of Kauffman Stadium, allowing future players to protect the legacy of the Royals' record books.\n\nAccording to MANICA, the Kansas-Missouri state line is uniquely aligned with the Right field fence, where home runs could literally be hit from one state into another.\n\nThe design would also integrate Kauffman's iconic water fountains and crown-shaped scoreboard.\n\nOther features of the conceptual ballpark include a mixed-use district with bars, restaurants, beer gardens, rooftop terraces and watch parties -- all with a stadium orientation that would frame downtown Kansas City's skyline.\n\nMANICA says its design master plan would include provisions for a hotel, offices, and residential lofts. It would have allowed state bonds to finance all stadium construction costs, but the latest version caps the amount at 70%, and it says legislative leaders and the governor must sign off on any bonding plan.\n\nSupporters of the plan also modified it so that it only applies to professional football and Major League Baseball stadiums, instead of any professional sports stadium for at least 30,000 spectators. Bonds would be paid off over 30 years.\n\n\"We're trying to bring something grand to the state of Kansas,\" said state Rep. Sean Tarwater, a Kansas City-area Republican leading the push for a stadium plan.\n\nFree-market conservatives in Kansas have long opposed state and local subsidies for specific businesses or projects. White issued the statement about an hour after the Kansas House approved a STAR bonds proposal for the Kansas City Chiefs and Kansas City Royals. He said his office remains open to speaking with the teams. \"In order to subsidize the renovation or construction of any stadium for privately owned sports teams, my stance remains clear: there must be a complete and transparent plan that offers tangible benefits to our taxpayers,\" White said. \"Ensuring we use taxpayer dollars responsibly is my top priority. My office remains open to conversations with the Royals, Chiefs, lawmakers, and other stakeholders, but any proposal must meet this standard and make sense for our community.\"Kansas Gov. Laura Kelly and Missouri Gov. Mike Parson announced a truce in 2019, which called for the end of using tax incentives to lure companies across the state. However, in March 2024, Kelly remarked the truce did not include the possibility of the Chiefs moving across state lines. \"I urge all stakeholders to honor the spirit of the 2019 truce and refrain from engaging in a counterproductive stadium bidding war,\" White said. \"Let us set a national example by prioritizing the well-being of our residents and fostering true economic cooperation across state lines.\" During multiple Jackson County Legislature meetings, White or representatives from his office said county officials remain in communication with the teams since the April 2 vote failed.\n\nJackson County Executive Frank White is calling on \"all stakeholders\" to honor the spirit of the 2019 Border War truce regarding economic development in Kansas and Missouri.\n\nWhite issued the statement about an hour after the Kansas House approved a STAR bonds proposal for the Kansas City Chiefs and Kansas City Royals.\n\nHe said his office remains open to speaking with the teams.\n\n\"In order to subsidize the renovation or construction of any stadium for privately owned sports teams, my stance remains clear: there must be a complete and transparent plan that offers tangible benefits to our taxpayers,\" White said. \"Ensuring we use taxpayer dollars responsibly is my top priority. {"uri": "8183861667", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "15:23:43", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T15:23:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T15:22:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.fieldofschemes.com/2024/06/18/21579/kansas-legislature-proposes-blank-check-for-billionaires-bill-to-lure-chiefs-royals-across-state-line/", "title": "Kansas legislature proposes \"blank check for billionaires\" bill to lure Chiefs, Royals across state line", "body": "Kansas legislators introduced a bill yesterday to provide public funding for new stadiums to lure the Kansas City Chiefs and Royals across state lines, and while we knew this was coming, we didn't know how much taxpayer money would be at stake. That's now coming into focus, and it looks like the public price tag is going to be a whole lot more than was previously revealed:\n\nHow much all this would add up to is unknowable, but if you're talking two $1-billion-plus stadiums, 75% of that would be anywhere from $1.5 billion to who knows, leading economist Geoffrey Propheter to call the bill \"a blank check for billionaires.\" In layman's terms, it would be a buttload of money to shell out in exchange for having two pro teams play on your side of the state line -- something Kansas would never recoup through new state tax revenues, and which would just contribute to the ever-worsening war between the states to see who'll exempt corporate titans from the most taxes, leaving the tax burden on other residents and business owners.\n\nThe Kansas legislature is set to start a special session today that will likely largely focus on stadium funding, but state legislators kicked things off last night by meeting at a local steakhouse with what the Kansas Reflector summed up as \"lobbyists, a Royals executive and representatives of organized labor,\" all of whom were seeking to convince them to rubber-stamp the plan. If that happens, Gov. Laura Kelly has already indicated she's likely to go along with whatever the legislature votes for, so this could get approved fairly quickly.\n\nWith so much still in flux, including how much the stadiums would cost and where they would go, we're looking at a two-stage process: first the passage of the bill authorizing stadium bonds, then actually figuring out what number to fill in on that blank check. Twitter is already calling out Missouri for getting pwned, and economist Twitter is clapping back that getting to watch Chiefs games while the state next door pays for the stadium seems like a pretty good deal for Missourians. Helgerson.\n\n\"As of today, we don't have the information to say that this was a good investment.\"\n\nKansas lawmakers pass STAR bonds bill to lure Chiefs, Royals\n\nHis other concern is that the bonds, and potential stadiums, will not positively impact the entire state, just the people in the Kansas City area.\n\n\"Until we have the information that says this is the best thing for everyone in this state, not just for selected individuals in the northeast part of the state... It's a it is a dramatic divergence from good public policy,\" said Helgerson.\n\nSince STAR bonds were introduced in 1999, the state has awarded more than half a billion dollars in bonds to Wyandotte and Johnson counties. Those bonds have been used to build Children's Mercy Park, the Kansas Speedway, and the Legends Outlets.\n\nThe rest of the state, from Atchison to Garden City, has received STAR bonds that number roughly $25 million dollars less than those given to Wyandotte and Johnson counties.\n\nRepresentative Helgerson said that the state is even changing the rules on STAR bonds to accommodate the potential stadiums.\n\n\"Cities around the state are going to come in and say if you gave this opportunity to Northeast Kansas, shouldn't it also be available to western Kansas or central Kansas?\" he asked.\n\nThose shopping at the Legends Outlets on Wednesday say they're happy to see the investment, and the idea of a new Chiefs Stadium near the stores excites them.\n\nKCK police say files leaked on dark web following recent cyberattack\n\n\"The more you can attract businesses and the more you can attract residences and create more of an active vibrant area, I think that would be great,\" said KCK native Briam Amaya.\n\n\"My opinion is that it's a positive choice. \"That would make me very excited that that would be here.\"\n\nZion Turner, who lives on the Missouri side of the city, said it doesn't matter what side of the state line the Chiefs play on.\n\n\"If it comes over here, it comes over here,\" said Turner.\n\n\"As long as the Chiefs aren't too far from home, that's all that matters to me.\"\n\nHe said that the investment into the Legends area has had a positive impact.\n\n\"Considering how everything else is looking, I think they're doing everything the right way and making pretty smart moves.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 Nexstar Media, Inc. Three Super Bowl victories in five years -- and player Travis Kelce's romance with pop icon Taylor Swift -- have made the Chiefs perhaps the area's most celebrated civic asset.\n\nBoth the Chiefs and the Royals said they look forward to considering Kansas options. The lease on the Missouri complex with the teams' side-by-side stadiums runs through January 2031, but both have said they already should have been planning for the future.\n\nBackers of the plan brushed aside decades of research by economists concluding that government subsidies for professional sports stadiums are not worth the cost. They also overcame criticism that lawmakers were moving too quickly.\n\nIt would allow state bonds to cover up to 70% of each new stadium, paying them off over 30 years with revenues from sports betting, state lottery ticket sales and new sales and alcohol taxes collected from shopping and entertainment districts around the new {"uri": "8184408196", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:44:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:44:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:43:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://www.ksn.com/news/capitol-bureau/kansas-lawmakers-pass-star-bonds-bill-to-lure-chiefs-royals/", "title": "Kansas lawmakers pass STAR bonds bill to lure Chiefs, Royals", "body": "TOPEKA, Kan. (WDAF) -- The Kansas House and Senate overwhelmingly passed the STAR bond legislation that was put up for a vote on both floors - the idea to lure the Kansas City Chiefs and the Royals across the state line.\n\n\"The state of Missouri is known for losing professional teams - not too long ago, they just lost the St. Louis Rams, they used to have a professional hockey team, the Scouts, they're gone, they had the Kansas City Kings, they're gone, so I ask you today, do you really want to put that kind of economic generation in the hands of the state of Missouri?\" Rep. Sean Tarwater (R-Kan.), who carried the bill, said on the House floor.\n\nThe passage of this bill means that the state could pay for up to 70% of the cost of the stadium project.\n\nThe bonds would be paid back over a thirty-year period from new sales taxes created in the district, liquor taxes in the district, and money generated by a sports wagering fund. Cities and counties could participate in the district or opt-out.\n\nThe district would be determined by the secretary of commerce as part of negotiations.\n\nPeople on the no side of this are clear: this is too big of a risk, and there is not enough information as to the benefit this would have and if, in the end, it would hurt Kansas taxpayers.\n\n\"I couldn't ensure myself that the taxpayers that I represent wouldn't ultimately be on the hook if this didn't work out. I think we do need more time. I don't know what the rush is, they say it has to be done yesterday, a lot of us - somebody is going to be back here in 6 months and why can't we spend the first week of our return if this is that important to deal with it at that point,\" Rep. Bob Lewis (R-Kan.) who voted no said.\n\nNevertheless, the opposition never stood a chance, with both votes getting more than enough, creating a super-majority vote situation. The House voted 84-38, while the Senate was 27-8.\n\nThe importance of having the supermajority support means that this is veto-proof if Kansas Gov. Laura Kelly decides to do that.\n\nHowever, that would be a surprise because every indication given from her office indicates she will sign this into law once it makes it to her desk.", "source": {"uri": "8186443714", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "06:23:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T06:23:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T06:23:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4509803950786591, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/chiefs-royals-moving-kansas-could-035138297.html", "title": "How Chiefs, Royals moving to Kansas could impact taxpayers", "body": "TOPEKA (KSNT) - Kansas now has the legislative leverage it needs to make an offer to Kansas City's professional sports teams, but how could state-funded stadiums impact taxpayers?\n\nKSNT 27 News spoke to the Dean of Washburn's Business School, David Sollars, who also teaches economics, to get the gist of what this star bond project could mean for taxpayers in the Sunflower State.\n\nSollars says the benefit of these bonds is that they don't increase taxes. The basic idea behind STAR bonds is that the projects they help fund will eventually pay for themselves.\n\nIf Kansas works out a deal with the Chiefs and/or Royals to help fund new stadiums, the money would be recouped from alcohol sales in potential stadium districts, as well as the revenue from sports gambling and the lottery. It would take 30 years to cover the cost.\n\nThe downside to these bonds, or opportunity cost as Sollars put it, is that those tax dollars can't go towards other public needs like roads or education.\n\nTopekans receive strange alert about man wanted for murder in two other states\n\nSollars also says from what he's seen of similar projects across the country, the long-term benefits can be extremely difficult to predict.\n\n\"This works great for the first five or ten years and then, unfortunately, the teams and the league move on to something new and different,\" Sollars said. \"And they want to renovate, and the repairs happen. There's this never-ending battle back and forth over who's responsible for this, that, and the other.\"\n\nSollars told 27 News at the end of the day, there is certainly some benefit, but the question is \"does that benefit outweigh the cost?\"\n\nBased on yesterday's vote, most lawmakers seem to believe they do. Governor Laura Kelly could still veto the bill, but she is expected to sign it based on previous testimony from her Chief of Staff.\n\nFor more local news, click here. The basic idea behind STAR bonds is that the projects they help fund will eventually pay for themselves.\n\nIf Kansas works out a deal with the Chiefs and/or Royals to help fund new stadiums, the money would be recouped from alcohol sales in potential stadium districts, as well as the revenue from sports gambling and the lottery. It would take 30 years to cover the cost.\n\nThe downside to these bonds, or opportunity cost as Sollars put it, is that those tax dollars can't go towards other public needs like roads or education.\n\nSollars also says from what he's seen of similar projects across the country, the long-term benefits can be extremely difficult to predict.\n\n\"This works great for the first five or ten years and then, unfortunately, the teams and the league move on to something new and different,\" Sollars said. \"And they want to renovate, and the repairs happen. There's this never-ending battle back and forth over who's responsible for this, that, and the other.\"\n\nSollars told 27 News at the end of the day, there is certainly some benefit, but the question is \"does that benefit outweigh the cost?\"\n\nBased on yesterday's vote, most lawmakers seem to believe they do. Governor Laura Kelly could still veto the bill, but she is expected to sign it based on previous testimony from her Chief of Staff.", "source": {"uri": "ksnt.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KSNT 27"}, "authors": [{"uri": "drew_gill@ksnt.com", "name": "Drew Gill", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bond_(finance)", "type": "wiki", "score": {"uri": "2024-06-395246334", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "23:59:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T23:59:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T23:48:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4392156898975372, "url": "https://www.kmbc.com/article/closer-look-at-star-bond-projects-in-kansas/61180045", "title": "As Chiefs and Royals consider options, a closer look at STAR Bond projects in Kansas", "body": "With the Chiefs and Royals now considering the option of moving to Kansas to build new stadiums partially financed by sales tax or STAR bonds, there have been mixed results on other STAR bond projects in the metro area.Under the plan, bondholders would lend the money, and it would be repaid by sales tax captured in a district, including the stadiums and other resulting businesses in the area.The first STAR bond project was for the Kansas Speedway.According to state records, there was $24.3 million in STAR bonds issued for that project in 1999 to be repaid over 30 years.Records show those bonds are likely to be paid off early.How we got here: A look back at what's led to recent discussion about the Chiefs, Royals' futures in the metro In 2010, Children's Mercy Park was given $150.3 million in STAR bonds.That debt has already been paid off.The U.S. Soccer Training facility is another STAR bonds project with $65.2 million in bonds issued in 2015.The debt service on that project is ongoing.\"STAR bonds have evolved since those times. And what we've done now is made it even better for the locals because we don't take away the local sales tax. That means that the local governments can use that money to invest in other areas, invest in lowering property taxes. And for me, that's a huge thing,\" said state Sen. Jeff Pittman, who voted for the STAR bond plan for the Chiefs and Royals on Tuesday. \"Obviously, one of the biggest deciding factors was, hey, we want to keep the Chiefs here. We want to keep the Royals here. And that means economic development using tools that have been proven to work here in Kansas,\" he said.Unified Government Commissioner Tom Burroughs worked on the Speedway project, the first STAR bonds project in the state of Kansas.He also testified on Monday before state lawmakers in Topeka supporting the STAR bond plan for the teams.\"We hope the past success of STAR bonds warrants strong consideration from the Chiefs and Royals,\" Burroughs said.Another STAR bonds project in Kansas City, Kansas, didn't happen as planned.The Schlitterbahn Water Park project received $85.2 million in STAR bonds in 2013.After the tragic death of Caleb Schwab in 2016, the water park closed. However, Kansas records show other businesses in that STAR bond district have replaced Schlitterbahn and are making STAR bond payments.There was roughly $6.2 million in sales tax revenues raised in the district in 2022.There have been two recent STAR bond projects in Overland Park.In 2012, about $65 million dollars in STAR bonds were issued for the Prairiefire project just south of 135th Street.That district features a retail area, a museum, and a meeting place.Prairiefire defaulted on its bond payments.\"I had colleagues who constantly beat the drum that we are not on the hook. And I gave them one reason: at the end, our prestige, our name in a business environment, is on the hook. If there is nothing else, if there is nothing else, a project which is constantly being portrayed in media as a failure, as something which can't pay back, is not the best way to advertise Overland Park,\" said former Overland Park City Councilman Faris Farassati.During debate on Tuesday, State Senator Molly Baumgardner criticized the ongoing Bluhawk Project which is in her district in south Overland Park.She said it's underperforming.In 2022, about $53 million in STAR bonds were given for Bluhawk which features commercial and residential property as well as plans for a 3500 seat arena for mixed use sports including hockey.Farassati voted against the plan.\"We just did not have the merits to be a STAR bond-qualified project. It is not a national point of interest. It wasn't a regional one either, and I don't know if a hockey rink would ever be a big thing in Kansas. We are not Canadian, so to speak, so we have to be realistic about this thing. I think Bluhawk was fantastic work by a bunch of lobbyists to sell that as a STAR bond-qualified project,\" he said.Both the Chiefs and Royals have issued statements praising Kansas lawmakers for giving them the option to consider building new stadiums in Kansas, in part, by using STAR bonds.Lawmakers have said the teams would also have to contribute hundreds of millions of dollars to make the projects work.Missouri leaders also say they're in ongoing negotiations with the Chiefs and Royals to keep them in the \"Show Me State.\"\n\nWith the Chiefs and Royals now considering the option of moving to Kansas to build new stadiums partially financed by sales tax or STAR bonds, there have been mixed results on other STAR bond projects in the metro area.\n\nUnder the plan, bondholders would lend the money, and it would be repaid by sales tax captured in a district, including the stadiums and other resulting businesses in the area.\n\nThe first STAR bond project was for the Kansas Speedway.\n\nAccording to state records, there was $24.3 million in STAR bonds issued for that project in 1999 to be repaid over 30 years.\n\nRecords show those bonds are likely to be paid off early.\n\nIn 2010, Children's Mercy Park was given $150.3 million in STAR bonds.\n\nThat debt has already been paid off.\n\nThe U.S. Soccer Training facility is another STAR bonds project with $65.2 million in bonds issued in 2015.\n\nThe debt service on that project is ongoing.\n\n\"STAR bonds have evolved since those times. And what we've done now is made it even better for the locals because we don't take away the local sales tax. That means that the local governments can use that money to invest in other areas, invest in lowering property taxes. And for me, that's a huge thing,\" said state Sen. Jeff Pittman, who voted for the STAR bond plan for the Chiefs and Royals on Tuesday.\n\n\"Obviously, one of the biggest deciding factors was, hey, we want to keep the Chiefs here. We want to keep the Royals here. And that means economic development using tools that have been proven to work here in Kansas,\" he said.\n\nUnified Government Commissioner Tom Burroughs worked on the Speedway project, the first STAR bonds project in the state of Kansas.\n\nHe also testified on Monday before state lawmakers in Topeka supporting the STAR bond plan for the teams.\n\n\"We hope the past success of STAR bonds warrants strong consideration from the Chiefs and Royals,\" Burroughs said.\n\nAnother STAR bonds project in Kansas City, Kansas, didn't happen as planned.\n\nThe Schlitterbahn Water Park project received $85.2 million in STAR bonds in 2013.\n\nAfter the tragic death of Caleb Schwab in 2016, the water park closed.\n\nHowever, Kansas records show other businesses in that STAR bond district have replaced Schlitterbahn and are making STAR bond payments.\n\nThere was roughly $6.2 million in sales tax revenues raised in the district in 2022.\n\nThere have been two recent STAR bond projects in Overland Park.\n\nIn 2012, about $65 million dollars in STAR bonds were issued for the Prairiefire project just south of 135th Street.\n\nThat district features a retail area, a museum, and a meeting place.\n\nPrairiefire defaulted on its bond payments.\n\n\"I had colleagues who constantly beat the drum that we are not on the hook. And I gave them one reason: at the end, our prestige, our name in a business environment, is on the hook. If there is nothing else, if there is nothing else, a project which is constantly being portrayed in media as a failure, as something which can't pay back, is not the best way to advertise Overland Park,\" said former Overland Park City Councilman Faris Farassati.\n\nDuring debate on Tuesday, State Senator Molly Baumgardner criticized the ongoing Bluhawk Project which is in her district in south Overland Park.\n\nShe said it's underperforming.\n\nIn 2022, about $53 million in STAR bonds were given for Bluhawk which features commercial and residential property as well as plans for a 3500 seat arena for mixed use sports including hockey.\n\nFarassati voted against the plan.\n\n\"We just did not have the merits to be a STAR bond-qualified project. It is not a national point of interest. It wasn't a regional one either, and I don't know if a hockey rink would ever be a big thing in Kansas. We are not Canadian, so to speak, so we have to be realistic about this thing. I think Bluhawk was fantastic work by a bunch of lobbyists to sell that as a STAR bond-qualified project,\" he said.\n\nBoth the Chiefs and Royals have issued statements praising Kansas lawmakers for giving them the option to consider building new stadiums in Kansas, in part, by using STAR bonds.\n\nLawmakers have said the teams would also have to contribute hundreds of millions of dollars to make the projects work.\n\nMissouri leaders also say they're in ongoing negotiations with the Chiefs and Royals to keep them in the \"Show Me State.\"", "source": {"uri": "kmbc.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8184668352", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:03:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:03:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:02:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://www.yakimaherald.com/morning-briefing-june-19-2024/article_9e0a3e5a-2df0-11ef-9268-977050e2848b.html", "title": "Morning Briefing: June 19, 2024", "body": "StadiumBill approved to lure Chiefs, Royals to Kansas\n\nTOPEKA, Kan. -- Kansas is making a serious run at becoming the new home for the reigning Super Bowl champions with legislators approving a plan Tuesday for luring both the Chiefs and Major League Baseball's Kansas City Royals away from Missouri.\n\nBipartisan legislative supermajorities OK'd the measure to authorize state bonds to help finance new stadiums and practice facilities for both teams on the Kansas side of the metropolitan area of 2.3 million residents, which is split by the border with Missouri. Three Super Bowl victories in five years -- and player Travis Kelce's romance with pop icon Taylor Swift -- have made the Chiefs perhaps the area's most celebrated civic asset.\n\nThe plan from the Republican-controlled Legislature goes next to Democratic Gov. Laura Kelly. While she stopped short of promising to sign it, she said in a statement that \"Kansas now has the opportunity to become a professional sports powerhouse.\"\n\nBoth the Chiefs and the Royals said they look forward to considering Kansas options. The lease on the Missouri complex with their side-by-side stadiums runs through January 2031, but both have said they already should have been planning for the future.\n\n\"We're excited about what happened here today,\" Korb Maxwell, an attorney for the Chiefs who lives on the Kansas side, said at the Statehouse after the bill cleared the Legislature. \"This is incredibly real.\"\n\nThe approval capped a two-month push to capitalize on the refusal in April by voters on the Missouri side to continue a local sales tax used to finance the upkeep of the teams' stadiums.\n\nSwimmingSmith sets world record in 100 back\n\nINDIANAPOLIS -- Bouncing back from a close-but-no-Olympics call in her first race, Regan Smith set a world record in the women's 100-meter backstroke at the U.S. swimming trials on Tuesday night.\n\nThe 22-year-old Minnesota native touched in 57.13 seconds, easily beating the mark of 57.33 set a year ago by Australia's Kaylee McKeown.\n\nSmith was just 17 years old when she first set a world record in the 100 back at the 2019 world championships. But she struggled to deal with the sudden, newfound fame, ceding dominance in the event to McKeown.\n\nKatharine Berkoff claimed the second expected Olympic spot for the U.S. with a time of 57.91.\n\nIn the night's other final, Bobby Finke earned the right to defend the 800 freestyle gold he won in Tokyo with a time of 7 minutes, 44.22 seconds.\n\nFinke had to work hard to get to the wall ahead of 18-year-old Indiana phenom Luke Whitlock, who set a national age-group record at 7:45.19 and will likely head to his first Olympics with the second U.S. spot.\n\nBoston College hires Torres: Boston College hired five-time Olympian Dara Torres as its swimming and diving coach to help the school rebuild the program after a hazing scandal. Torres, 57, will coach both the men and women.\n\nBriefly\n\nBaseball: Astros ace Justin Verlander went on the IL with lingering neck discomfort. ... Yankees star Aaron Judge said X-rays and a CT scan were negative after he was hit on the left hand. ... Orioles third baseman Jordan Westburg left a game with left hip discomfort after colliding with Juan Soto. ... The Cubs placed outfielder Mike Tauchman on theIL with a left groin strain. ... The Twins will place outfielder Alex Kirilloff on the IL with back trouble. ... Gerrit Cole will make his season debut for the Yankees on Wednesday. ... Anthony Rizzo was placed on the IL by the Yankees with a broken right forearm. ... The Blue Jays put shortstop Bo Bichette on the IL with a sore right calf. ... Guardians third baseman Jos\u00e9 Ram\u00edrez was activated from the paternity list.\n\nBasketball: Sparks rookie Cameron Brink had to be helped off the court after suffering a knee injury. ... Aces point guard Chelsea Gray, who has not played since injuring her left foot in last season's WNBA Finals, is expected to make her season debut Wednesday.\n\nFootball: The Bears signed veteran receiver and return specialist DeAndre Carter to a one-year contract.\n\nHockey: The Utah Hockey Club named Chris Armstrong president of hockey operations. ... The Hurricanes officially promoted Eric Tulsky to general manager. ... The Canucks signed defenseman Filip Hronek to an eight-year extension with an average annual value of $7.25 million. ... The Blues signed defenseman Scott Perunovich to a $1.15 million contract for next season. ... The Rangers put Barclay Goodrow on waivers.\n\nCourt: The Washington Commanders settled a lawsuit with Virginia over their handling of season-ticket deposits under previous ownership, the last litigation remaining from that situation a decade ago. The $1.3 million settlement with Virginia includes returning $600,000 to nearly 500 fans who were affected.\n\nMotor sports: Arrow McLaren made yet another driver change when it signed 19-year-old Nolan Siegel to drive the remainder of the IndyCar season. He will be the third driver to race the No. 6 this year.\n\nTennis: Carlos Alcaraz began his grass-court season by beating Francisco Cerundolo 6-1, 7-5 in his opener at Queen's Club.\n\nTrack and field: Sprinting great Michael Johnson is launching a track league that looks to assemble nearly 100 of the sport's top performers four times a year to compete for $12.6 million in prize money over its first season. The league, Grand Slam Track, announced that it will launch next April with plans for one event in Los Angeles, the home of the 2028 Olympics, one in another American city and two more overseas.\n\nObituary: Bob Schul, the only American distance runner to win gold in the 5,000 meters at the Olympics, has died.
